children.definition: Hard dollar floor component of the general debt basket, providing a minimum capacity level regardless of EBITDA. Ranges from $10-20M in LMM to $40-100M in UMM, with BSL at $75-200M. Distinguished from the EBITDA percentage prong by being static — does not change with business performance. In a 'greater of' structure, this dollar amount prevents the basket from shrinking below a floor if EBITDA declines.
children.name: Fixed Dollar Amount

children.definition: EBITDA-linked grower component of the general debt basket, expressed as a percentage of LTM EBITDA. Enables the basket to scale with business growth but also to shrink during downturns. Market ranges: LMM 15-20%, CMM 20-30%, aggressive UMM/BSLR 40-50% (PC Term Comparison). Distinguished from the fixed dollar prong by being dynamic. KCT Cat 2 Item 4 flags 'high water marking' risk where the basket is permanently reset to the highest EBITDA ever reported, preventing the basket from declining even as EBITDA falls.

children.definition: Whether the general debt basket uses a 'greater of' dual-prong structure combining a fixed dollar floor with an EBITDA percentage. DLS Preferred Row 89 alternative: 'Dollar baskets to also include a grower based on EBITDA or Total Assets.' The 'greater of' formulation is the dominant market structure in private credit. Distinguished from fixed-dollar-only or EBITDA-only variants by providing both downside protection (floor) and upside scalability (grower).

children.definition: Whether the grower basket is permanently reset to the highest EBITDA ever reported, preventing the basket from declining even as EBITDA falls. KCT Cat 2 Item 4: 'grower baskets are deemed to be increased to the highest amount of the grower component reached from time to time and such grower basket is not subsequently reduced as a result of any decrease in the grower component that may result from asset sales, underperformance or otherwise.' PC Term Comparison: 'Greater of actual closing and hardwired leverage levels: Reject. Greater of pro forma EBITDA and highest previous reported EBITDA: Reject.'

children.definition: Whether the cap measures total debt ever incurred under the basket ('aggregate incurred') or only currently outstanding debt ('outstanding at any time'). An 'outstanding' measurement allows revolving usage: debt repaid and re-incurred does not consume permanent capacity. An 'aggregate' measurement prevents recycling but may be overly restrictive for operational debt needs.

children.definition: Sizing formulation for the general debt basket. Three variants: (1) fixed dollar only — a single hard dollar cap with no growth mechanism (bank preferred per DLS); (2) EBITDA grower only — sole percentage-of-EBITDA basket that scales with business growth; (3) 'greater of' combination — the dominant market structure where the basket equals the greater of a fixed dollar floor and a percentage of LTM EBITDA, providing a minimum floor that grows with EBITDA (DLS Row 89 alternative: 'Dollar baskets to also include a grower based on EBITDA or Total Assets').

children.definition: Whether debt incurred under the general basket can be secured by liens. PC Term Comparison line 407: 'Avoid having both a general liens basket and a crossing lien to general debt basket.' If secured debt is permitted, the basket interacts with the liens covenant — a corresponding lien permission must exist. Distinguished from the security type (which specifies priority) by being the threshold yes/no permission.

children.definition: Type of security permitted for general basket debt: pari passu first lien, junior lien, or unsecured. Pari passu is the most aggressive — allows new first-lien debt without a leverage test. PC Term Comparison: 'Focus on non Loan-Party debt and general debt capacity in particular structurally senior debt and debt secured by non-Collateral and ability to bring in more pari secured debt not subject to closing 1L leverage.' Distinguished from the can_be_secured binary by specifying the priority level.

children.definition: Conditions governing when the general debt basket can be used. PC clients generally prefer event-of-default stoppers on baskets that would ordinarily have them, not limited to payment/bankruptcy stoppers, especially on incurrence baskets (PC Term Comparison). Distinguished from ratio debt conditions (which require leverage test compliance) by typically requiring only an EoD check, not a financial test.
dls_ref: DLS:11:Conditions to incurrence: Bring down of
children.name: Conditions to Incurrence

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: “All-in Yield” all-in yield (including interest rate margins, any interest rate floors, original issue discount and upfront fees (based on the lesser of a four-year average life to maturity or the remaining life to maturity), but excluding reasonable and customary arrangement, structuring and underwriting fees) applicable to any Incremental Term Loans will not be more than 0.50% higher than the corresponding all-in yield (determined on the same basis) applicable to the Term Loans and any existing Incremental Term Loans (each an “Existing Term Loan”), unless the interest rate margin with respect to each applicable Existing Term Loan is increased by an amount equal to the difference between the all-in yield with respect to such Incremental Term Loans and the all-in yield on such Existing Term Loans as applicable, minus, 0.50%; it being agreed that to the extent the all-in yield with respect to such Incremental Term Loans is greater than such all-in yield with respect to any Existing Term Loans solely as a result of a higher interest rate floor, then the interest rate margin increase shall be effectuated solely by increasing the interest rate floor on any applicable Existing Term Loans. [...]
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: MFN protection for life (lender) vs no MFN (borrower). Market typically has sunset (12-24 months). | ROFR required (lender) vs no ROFR. Market mixed — PC typically requires, BSL typically does not. | Strict maturity floors (lender) vs inside-maturity thresholds (borrower). Market allows limited inside-maturity amounts. | Pro rata sharing (lender) vs flexible waterfall (borrower). Market standard: mandatory prepayments pro rata; voluntary may be flexible.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position:
Conditions to incurrence:
Bring down of all representations and warranties
No default or event of default
must have a ROFR on all Incremental Facilities
Required Terms and other provisions of the Incremental Facility:
Collateral: Can only be secured by Collateral and must be pari passu with the Term Facility [...]

children.definition: Whether the non-guarantor sublimit for the general basket is shared with non-guarantor caps from other debt baskets (ratio debt, acquisition debt, IED). PC Term Comparison: non-guarantor caps apply universally. Shared caps reduce complexity but allow the borrower to allocate capacity between baskets. Distinguished from standalone non-guarantor limits by pooling multiple basket restrictions.

children.definition: Sub-limit within the general debt basket for indebtedness at non-loan-party subsidiaries. Structurally senior to lender claims since non-guarantor creditors have priority over the subsidiary's assets. PC Term Comparison: 'Focus on non Loan-Party debt and general debt capacity in particular structurally senior debt and debt secured by non-Collateral.' Often shared with other non-guarantor caps. Distinguished from the overall basket cap by limiting the portion that can be incurred at non-guarantor entities.

children.definition: Fixed-dollar 'catch-all' debt basket not tied to any leverage ratio test or specific transaction purpose. Available for any borrowing need without conditions beyond the size cap. The bank's preferred position includes only a general fixed-dollar basket (DLS Preferred Row 79). Market sizing is 'greater of' a dollar amount and an EBITDA percentage, with LMM at 15-20% EBITDA, CMM at 20-30%, and aggressive UMM/BSLR at 40-50% (PC Term Comparison). Distinguished from ratio debt (which requires pro forma leverage compliance) by having no financial test — capacity is determined solely by the basket size.

entries.description: General debt basket providing uncircumscribed debt capacity not tied to ratio tests, typically structured as
entries.label: Indebtedness - General Basket

entries.description: Negative covenant providing uncircumscribed debt capacity not tied to financial ratio tests, typically structured as greater of fixed dollar amount and EBITDA percentage.
entries.label: Limitation on Indebtedness - General Basket

concept_specific_keywords: in an aggregate principal amount not to exceed
concept_specific_notes: [neg_cov_debt.general_basket] Never called 'general basket' in agreement text (0/9 verbatim). Only 2/9 (LendingTree, Viavi) define it as 'General Debt Basket'. Others use 'other Indebtedness of the Borrower or any Restricted Subsidiary in an aggregate principal amount not to exceed...' — 'in an aggregate principal amount not to exceed' is the most universal anchor. Removed 'not otherwise permitted hereunder' (1/9, near-dead).
search_strategy.fallback_escalation: Search for 'shall not incur' or 'Permitted Indebtedness' or 'incurrence of Indebtedness'. If none found, search for 'other Indebtedness' or 'aggregate principal amount' near negative covenant headings.

Cross-references to ratio test / Leverage Ratio definition
Cross-references to Permitted Acquisition / Limited Condition Acquisition
Section 2.14/2.20 for Incremental Facility mechanics (incremental_facility basket lives there, not in neg cov section)

children.definition: Pro forma first lien net leverage threshold for pari passu secured ratio debt. Learning Material: 'First lien leverage ratio prong is usually opening first lien leverage ratio (closing date leverage after giving effect to the Transactions).' DLS Preferred Row 9: 'a Senior Net Leverage Ratio not to exceed the Senior Net Leverage Ratio on the Closing Date.' PC Term Comparison: 'set at equivalent closing level.' Distinguished from secured and total leverage tiers by being the most restrictive test for the highest-priority debt.
children.name: First Lien Net Leverage Ratio

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position:
Limited to debt for borrowed money capital lease obligations/purchase money debt and obligations evidenced by bonds, debentures notes and similar instruments
No cap on cash netting
No requirement to keep the unrestricted cash in deposit account subject to a control agreement [...]
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Spectrum from fixed-dollar cap (lender) to ratio-based (borrower). Market often lands on greater-of formulation.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: First Lien Net Leverage for pari passu incurrence test; most restrictive ratio tier. Cash netting capped at fixed dollar amount

children.definition: Leverage ratio thresholds governing ratio debt incurrence, tiered by debt seniority. Typical structure: first lien leverage for pari passu debt, total secured leverage for junior lien debt, total leverage (or interest coverage) for unsecured debt. Learning Material: 'First lien leverage ratio prong is usually opening first lien leverage ratio (closing date leverage after giving effect to the Transactions).' PC Term Comparison: 'set at equivalent closing level; no headroom other than occasionally up to 0.25x for junior lien and 0.25-0.50x for unsecured.'

children.definition: Whether the ratio is tested only at incurrence (point-in-time) or on an ongoing maintenance basis. Ratio debt uses incurrence-only testing — the borrower need only satisfy the leverage test at the moment of debt incurrence, not thereafter. Distinguished from financial maintenance covenants (which are tested quarterly) by allowing capacity to be locked in at incurrence regardless of subsequent EBITDA deterioration.

children.definition: How pro forma EBITDA and debt are computed for the ratio test. Learning Material: ratio test is computed 'after giving pro forma effect to such incurrence (and any related acquisitions, investments or other specified transactions).' LTM EBITDA with acquisition adjustments, cost savings, and synergies per DLS Preferred Row 72. Distinguished from the cash netting question by governing the numerator (debt) and denominator (EBITDA) calculation methodology.

children.definition: Whether the borrower can elect to test the ratio at signing rather than closing of an acquisition (Limited Condition Transaction). DLS Preferred Row 15: 'Borrower may elect to test any Ratios/Baskets/Conditions required to be complied with in connection with such LCA at the time of signing the definitive documentation.' PC Term Comparison: 'LCA testing provisions only available for LCAs to be consummated within 120 days.' Distinguished from standard incurrence testing by locking in compliance at a pre-closing measurement date.

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 15; PC Term Comparison

children.definition: Whether unrestricted cash can be netted from debt for ratio calculation. DLS Preferred Row 13: cash netting 'not to exceed $[X]; provided such unrestricted Cash and cash equivalents are held in deposit accounts subject to control agreements.' DLS Alternative: 'No cap on cash netting. No requirement to keep the unrestricted cash in deposit account subject to a control agreement.' PC Term Comparison: 'Discuss cap on cash netting. Discuss whether DACAs apply and if so limit netting to DACA cash.' Distinguished from proceeds netting (which concerns new debt proceeds) by governing existing cash balances.

iridium.value: All unrestricted cash is permitted to be net from debt

children.definition: Minimum ratio level below which the no-worse prong cannot be used. If closing leverage was 4.5x and EBITDA subsequently grows, the no-worse test at 3.0x would permit new debt even though 3.0x is well below closing. A floor prevents this by requiring the ratio to be tested against the closing level rather than the current level.

children.definition: Whether the no-worse prong is limited to acquisition financing only. PC Term Comparison: 'if agreed limit it to acquisitions.' This is the typical compromise — the borrower can only use the no-worse test when incurring debt to fund a permitted acquisition, not for general-purpose borrowing. Distinguished from the unrestricted no-worse prong by requiring a qualifying transaction.

children.definition: Whether MFN price protection governs ratio debt incurrence. PC Term Comparison: 'MFN will generally apply in all transactions including Aggressive UMM/BSLR.' DLS Preferred Row 11: '50 bps of MFN for life.' The presence of MFN is the threshold question; trigger, sunset, and scope are negotiated details.
children.name: MFN Applies

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position:
Include incremental equivalent debt
Other Debt Baskets:
(i) “Ratio Debt Basket”: Basket for incurring debt based on any combination of senior, secured and unsecured leverage ratio baskets and/or a fixed charge coverage ratio. This debt would be incurred “outside” our credit agreement (i.e. under a separate facility). If permitted there would need to be restrictions on (i) terms of new debt, (ii) no shorter maturity/WAL, (iii) restrictions on mandatory and voluntary prepayments, (iv) MFN protection on yield and (v) non-guarantor sub-limits. [...]
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Spectrum from fixed-dollar cap (lender) to ratio-based (borrower). Market often lands on greater-of formulation.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position:
(i) indebtedness under the Credit Facilities [(including any incremental, delayed draw and refinancing facilities permitted thereunder)]
(ii) a fixed dollar general debt basket
(iii) [debt incurred in connection with Permitted Acquisitions in an amount and on terms to be agreed]

children.definition: Months after which MFN protection on ratio debt expires. DLS Preferred: no sunset ('MFN for life'). PC Term Comparison: 'Aggressive UMM/BSLR: 12-18 months. Otherwise no sunset.' DLS alternative: '12/24 months sunset on MFN.' Distinguished from the trigger (which sets the basis point threshold) by governing the temporal scope.
children.name: Sunset Period (months)

red_flags.market_context: Without maturity/WALM limits, new debt can effectively prime existing lenders via earlier maturity

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 11; PC Term Comparison lines 228-230

children.definition: What debt types the MFN covers when triggered by ratio debt incurrence. PC Term Comparison: 'Aggressive UMM/BSLR: pari term loans only. Otherwise all pari debt including debt securities and IED, Ratio debt, incurred acquisition debt and any other ratio baskets.' Distinguished from the trigger (which sets the sensitivity) by governing the breadth of debt covered.
children.name: MFN Scope

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position:
Include incremental equivalent debt
Other Debt Baskets:
(i) “Ratio Debt Basket”: Basket for incurring debt based on any combination of senior, secured and unsecured leverage ratio baskets and/or a fixed charge coverage ratio. This debt would be incurred “outside” our credit agreement (i.e. under a separate facility). If permitted there would need to be restrictions on (i) terms of new debt, (ii) no shorter maturity/WAL, (iii) restrictions on mandatory and voluntary prepayments, (iv) MFN protection on yield and (v) non-guarantor sub-limits. [...]
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Spectrum from fixed-dollar cap (lender) to ratio-based (borrower). Market often lands on greater-of formulation.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position:
(i) indebtedness under the Credit Facilities [(including any incremental, delayed draw and refinancing facilities permitted thereunder)]
(ii) a fixed dollar general debt basket
(iii) [debt incurred in connection with Permitted Acquisitions in an amount and on terms to be agreed]

children.definition: Definition of all-in yield for MFN comparison. DLS Preferred Row 11 alternative: 'All-in Yield including interest rate margins, any interest rate floors, original issue discount and upfront fees (based on the lesser of a four-year average life to maturity or the remaining life to maturity), but excluding reasonable and customary arrangement, structuring and underwriting fees.' PC Term Comparison: 'Use conservative definition of All In Yield.' Distinguished from the trigger threshold by defining what is measured rather than the sensitivity of the measurement.

children.definition: Structural restrictions on terms of ratio debt. These mirror incremental facility controls but apply to debt incurred outside the credit agreement.

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 alternative

children.definition: Unlimited debt capacity incurred outside the credit agreement (under a separate facility) subject to pro forma compliance with specified leverage ratios. The bank's preferred position is 'No such basket' (DLS Preferred Row 79 alternative). When permitted, ratio debt shares capacity with the incremental facility's ratio prong and is subject to restrictions on terms, maturity/WALM, non-guarantor sublimits, and MFN protection. The 'no-worse' prong and FCCR prong are 'typically rejected including in UMM/BSLR transactions' (PC Term Comparison). Distinguished from incremental facilities (which sit inside the credit agreement) by being incurred under separate documentation, and from IED (which counts against incremental capacity) by having its own standalone capacity.

entries.description: Ratio-based debt capacity that is unlimited if pro forma leverage tests are satisfied, typically mirroring incremental facility ratio tests by seniority.
entries.label: Indebtedness - Ratio Debt

entries.description: Unlimited debt capacity available if pro forma leverage ratio tests are satisfied, typically tiered by seniority with separate thresholds for first lien, second lien, and unsecured debt.
entries.label: Limitation on Indebtedness - Ratio Debt

concept_specific_notes: [neg_cov_debt.incremental_equiv_debt_cov] Incremental Equivalent Debt (5/9, 103 hits). Boyd calls its equivalent 'Ratio Debt' instead. Removed 'substantially equivalent' (0/9 in debt sections — only appears in definitions). Not present in Arch, Sleep Number, National Vision, Caesars (these deals lack IED mechanics entirely).
search_strategy.fallback_escalation: Search for 'shall not incur' or 'Permitted Indebtedness' or 'incurrence of Indebtedness'. If none found, search for 'other Indebtedness' or 'aggregate principal amount' near negative covenant headings.

Cross-references to ratio test / Leverage Ratio definition
Cross-references to Permitted Acquisition / Limited Condition Acquisition
Section 2.14/2.20 for Incremental Facility mechanics (incremental_facility basket lives there, not in neg cov section)

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 alternative ('Ratio Debt Basket'); PC Term Comparison lines 381-385

children.definition: How IED capacity is defined. Three structures: (1) standalone basket with its own dollar cap, (2) shared capacity that draws from incremental accordion, or (3) unlimited subject to ratio test. DLS Preferred Row 12 alternative: IED 'may be issued in lieu of the accordion.' Distinguished from the fixed amount by governing the structural relationship to incremental capacity.
children.name: Structure Type

red_flags.market_context: DLS preferred: no such basket; alternative requires same terms and conditions
red_flags.text: Incremental Equivalent Debt (IED) basket exists without same protections as incremental facility — potential circumvention vehicle

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 12 alternative

children.definition: Fixed dollar cap on IED when structured as a standalone basket rather than shared with incremental capacity. When specified, provides a hard ceiling independent of leverage conditions. Distinguished from the shared-with-incremental structure by having its own dedicated capacity pool.
children.name: Fixed Amount

red_flags.market_context: DLS preferred: no such basket; alternative requires same terms and conditions
red_flags.text: Incremental Equivalent Debt (IED) basket exists without same protections as incremental facility — potential circumvention vehicle

children.definition_source: Review Template Row 24 (Incremental Amount – freebie); Review Template Row 25 (Incremental Amount – prepayments); Review Template Row 26 (Incremental Amount – ratio)

children.definition: Whether IED draws from the same free-and-clear capacity pool as incremental facilities. DLS Preferred Row 12 alternative: IED 'may be issued in lieu of the accordion, and any such debt shall be subject to the same terms and conditions as the incremental facility.' Usage under IED reduces available incremental capacity dollar-for-dollar.
children.name: Shared With Incremental

red_flags.market_context: DLS preferred: no such basket; alternative requires same terms and conditions
red_flags.text: Incremental Equivalent Debt (IED) basket exists without same protections as incremental facility — potential circumvention vehicle

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 12 alternative

children.definition: Sizing structure for IED. DLS Preferred Row 12 alternative: IED 'may be issued in lieu of the accordion, and any such debt shall be subject to the same terms and conditions as the incremental facility.' Capacity shares with the incremental accordion — usage under IED reduces available incremental capacity. Can draw from either the free-and-clear or ratio prong.
children.name: Capacity Structure

red_flags.market_context: DLS preferred: no such basket; alternative requires same terms and conditions
red_flags.text: Incremental Equivalent Debt (IED) basket exists without same protections as incremental facility — potential circumvention vehicle

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 12 alternative

children.definition: Leverage ratio for pari passu IED. Mirrors the first lien incremental ratio test. DLS Preferred Row 9: 'first lien net leverage ratio would be no greater than closing date first lien net leverage.' Distinguished from junior lien and unsecured ratios by using the most restrictive test for the most senior IED.
children.name: Pari Passu Ratio

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Incremental Equivalent Debt permitted to be incurred in the form of senior secured notes or loans, either on a pari passu [NOTE: sometimes pari passu incremental equivalent debt only permitted in respect of notes] or junior basis, subordinated notes or loans or senior unsecured notes or loans and/or secured or unsecured mezzanine debt may be issued in lieu of the accordion, and any such debt shall be subject to the same terms and conditions as the incremental facility. No MFN on pari passu notes.
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Lender prefers prohibition; borrower seeks permission. Market typically allows with conditions.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: No such basket

red_flags.market_context: DLS preferred: no such basket; alternative requires same terms and conditions
red_flags.text: Incremental Equivalent Debt (IED) basket exists without same protections as incremental facility — potential circumvention vehicle

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 9 alternative; Learning Material line 1443

children.definition: Leverage ratio for junior/second lien IED. Uses total secured leverage with a cushion vs. first lien. DLS Preferred Row 9 alternative: 'Secured Net Leverage Ratio would be no greater than closing date Secured Net Leverage.' PC Term Comparison: 'up to 0.25x for junior lien.' Distinguished from pari passu ratio by using a broader leverage measure.
children.name: Junior Lien Ratio

red_flags.market_context: DLS preferred: no such basket; alternative requires same terms and conditions
red_flags.text: Incremental Equivalent Debt (IED) basket exists without same protections as incremental facility — potential circumvention vehicle

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 9 alternative; PC Term Comparison line 222

children.definition: Leverage ratio for unsecured IED. Highest threshold using total leverage or interest coverage ratio. DLS Preferred Row 9 alternative: 'Total Net Leverage Ratio would be no greater than closing date Total Net Leverage or pro forma compliance with a 2.0x cash interest coverage ratio.' PC Term Comparison: '0.25-0.50x for unsecured.' Distinguished from secured tiers by capturing all debt and offering a coverage ratio alternative.
children.name: Unsecured Ratio

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position:
Include incremental equivalent debt
Other Debt Baskets:
(i) “Ratio Debt Basket”: Basket for incurring debt based on any combination of senior, secured and unsecured leverage ratio baskets and/or a fixed charge coverage ratio. This debt would be incurred “outside” our credit agreement (i.e. under a separate facility). If permitted there would need to be restrictions on (i) terms of new debt, (ii) no shorter maturity/WAL, (iii) restrictions on mandatory and voluntary prepayments, (iv) MFN protection on yield and (v) non-guarantor sub-limits. [...]
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Spectrum from fixed-dollar cap (lender) to ratio-based (borrower). Market often lands on greater-of formulation.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position:
(i) indebtedness under the Credit Facilities [(including any incremental, delayed draw and refinancing facilities permitted thereunder)]
(ii) a fixed dollar general debt basket
(iii) [debt incurred in connection with Permitted Acquisitions in an amount and on terms to be agreed]

children.definition: Per-tier leverage ratio tests for different security levels of IED. DLS Preferred Row 9 alternative establishes tiered structure: first lien at closing FLLR, junior lien at closing secured leverage, unsecured at closing total leverage or 2.0x FCCR. Each tier uses a different ratio appropriate to its collateral position. Distinguished from the aggregate IED capacity by allocating capacity across security types.

children.definition: Whether incremental equivalent debt issued outside the credit agreement in the form of notes, bonds, or other instruments is subject to the same most-favored-nation pricing protection as incremental term loans incurred under the credit agreement. DLS Preferred Row 12: 'No MFN on pari passu notes.' PC Term Comparison: 'MFN will generally apply in all transactions including Aggressive UMM/BSLR' — the tension between bank-preferred note exemption and market practice makes this a key negotiation point.
children.name: MFN Applies

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Incremental Equivalent Debt permitted to be incurred in the form of senior secured notes or loans, either on a pari passu [NOTE: sometimes pari passu incremental equivalent debt only permitted in respect of notes] or junior basis, subordinated notes or loans or senior unsecured notes or loans and/or secured or unsecured mezzanine debt may be issued in lieu of the accordion, and any such debt shall be subject to the same terms and conditions as the incremental facility. No MFN on pari passu notes.
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Lender prefers prohibition; borrower seeks permission. Market typically allows with conditions.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: No such basket

children.definition: Whether incremental equivalent debt issued on a junior lien or unsecured basis is exempt from the MFN pricing protection. Standard market practice exempts non-pari IED because MFN protection addresses repricing risk among instruments sharing the same collateral and payment priority. Junior lien and unsecured debt carry inherently different credit profiles that make yield comparisons inapplicable.

children.definition: Whether incremental equivalent debt must mature no earlier than the existing credit facility maturity date. DLS Preferred Row 9: incremental 'Maturity Date: No earlier than the maturity date of the Term Facility.' This protection applies to IED through same-terms alignment. PC Term Comparison: 'WALM/Maturity/Inside maturity carveouts: Aggressive UMM/BSLR may not have these protections (or a cap on inside maturing debt); otherwise Clients will expect these protections.'

children.definition: Whether incremental equivalent debt must have a weighted average life to maturity no shorter than the remaining WALM of the existing term loans. DLS Preferred Row 11: 'Weighted Average Life to Maturity: No shorter weighted average life to maturity than the Term Facility.' WALM prevents structuring incremental equivalent debt with accelerated amortization that would effectively mature before existing loans despite a nominal later maturity date.

children.definition: Whether customary bridge financing arrangements with automatic conversion to or takeout by permanent instruments are exempted from the maturity and WALM constraints applicable to incremental equivalent debt. Bridge facilities typically have short initial maturities (6-12 months) that would violate inside-maturity prohibitions, but their temporary nature and automatic conversion mechanics mitigate the structural risk that maturity floors are designed to prevent.
children.name: Bridge-to-Takeout

children.definition: Maturity and WALM requirements for IED. DLS Preferred Row 9 alternative: 'To the extent the Credit Facility provides the ability to incur junior lien or unsecured debt, thought must be given to maturity date (i.e. mature at least 180 days outside Credit Facility).' PC Term Comparison: 'Maturity/WALM: would also apply to IED, Ratio Debt, incurred acquisition debt.' Aggressive UMM/BSLR: 'may give a basket up to 50-100% of EBITDA' for inside-maturing debt.
children.name: Maturity & WALM

children.definition: Debt incurred outside the credit agreement in the form of notes or loans that counts against incremental facility capacity. DLS Preferred Row 12: bank preferred position is 'No such basket.' Alternative: 'Incremental Equivalent Debt permitted to be incurred in the form of senior secured notes or loans, either on a pari passu or junior basis, subordinated notes or loans or senior unsecured notes or loans and/or secured or unsecured mezzanine debt may be issued in lieu of the accordion, and any such debt shall be subject to the same terms and conditions as the incremental facility. No MFN on pari passu notes.' PC Term Comparison: MFN applies to IED in all transactions. Distinguished from ratio debt (which has independent capacity) by consuming incremental accordion capacity.

entries.description: Ratio-based debt capacity that is unlimited if pro forma leverage tests are satisfied, typically mirroring incremental facility ratio tests by seniority.
entries.label: Indebtedness - Ratio Debt

entries.description: Unlimited debt capacity available if pro forma leverage ratio tests are satisfied, typically tiered by seniority with separate thresholds for first lien, second lien, and unsecured debt.
entries.label: Limitation on Indebtedness - Ratio Debt

concept_specific_notes: [neg_cov_debt.incremental_equiv_debt_cov] Incremental Equivalent Debt (5/9, 103 hits). Boyd calls its equivalent 'Ratio Debt' instead. Removed 'substantially equivalent' (0/9 in debt sections — only appears in definitions). Not present in Arch, Sleep Number, National Vision, Caesars (these deals lack IED mechanics entirely).
search_strategy.fallback_escalation: Search for 'shall not incur' or 'Permitted Indebtedness' or 'incurrence of Indebtedness'. If none found, search for 'other Indebtedness' or 'aggregate principal amount' near negative covenant headings.

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 12; PC Term Comparison lines 381-382

children.definition: Whether the pro forma leverage thresholds governing acquisition-specific incurrence match the general incurrence ratio levels used for incremental and ratio debt. DLS Preferred Row 79 (alternative): incurred acquisition ratio debt is 'subject to the same ratio levels' as the ratio debt basket. When thresholds are aligned, acquisition debt does not create additional headroom beyond general ratio capacity; when they diverge (especially via 'no worse' prongs), acquisition-specific incurrence can exceed the leverage ceiling available for general-purpose debt.
children.name: Tracks Ratio Debt
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 (alternative: 'same ratio levels'); PC Term Comparison line 383 ('no worse' typically rejected)

children.definition: Whether a dedicated fixed-dollar amount exists for acquisition debt that can be incurred without satisfying a pro forma leverage test, analogous to the free-and-clear prong for incremental facilities. A separate starter for acquisition debt provides certain-funds capacity for acquisitions even when the borrower cannot pass the ratio test. DLS Preferred Row 79: 'debt incurred in connection with Permitted Acquisitions in an amount and on terms to be agreed' — the bank-preferred position is a fixed cap rather than ratio-based capacity.
children.name: Separate Starter Prong

red_flags.pattern: Separate large starter prong for acquisition debt

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 (acquisition debt: 'amount and terms to be agreed')

children.definition: Dollar amount of the dedicated fixed-dollar starter basket for incurred acquisition debt, expressed as either a standalone amount or a greater-of dollar/EBITDA percentage structure. Sizing depends on deal size and expected acquisition activity. DLS Preferred Row 79: basket (iii) is 'debt incurred in connection with Permitted Acquisitions in an amount and on terms to be agreed' — sizing is deal-specific. The acquisition debt starter is typically smaller than the general debt basket because ratio capacity provides the primary acquisition financing vehicle.

iridium.value: Greater of $155M / 35% EBITDA (if by Loan Parties)

children.name: Starter Amount
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 (basket (iii) acquisition debt)

children.definition: EBITDA percentage component of the grower structure for the incurred acquisition debt starter basket, which automatically increases the basket as EBITDA grows. When structured as 'greater of $X and Y% of LTM EBITDA,' the EBITDA percentage provides a floor that scales with borrower size. KCT Cat 2 Item 4 (high water marking risk): 'grower baskets are deemed to be increased to the highest amount of the grower component reached from time to time and such grower basket is not subsequently reduced.'
children.name: Starter EBITDA Percentage
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 2 Item 4 (high water marking for grower baskets)

children.definition: The method by which incurred acquisition debt capacity is determined: either through a ratio-based leverage test (unlimited if pro forma compliance is achieved), a fixed-dollar starter basket, or a combination of both. DLS Preferred Row 79 (alternative): 'Incurred Acquisition Ratio Debt Basket: Same considerations as Ratio Debt Basket (and subject to the same ratio levels) however some Sponsors will ask for the leverage ratios to be no worse.' Capacity determination involves the same tiered structure as incremental facilities.
children.name: Capacity Structure
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 (alternative: Incurred Acquisition Ratio Debt Basket)

children.definition: First lien net leverage ratio threshold for incurring pari passu acquisition debt on an unlimited basis. Set at or near closing leverage to ensure no deterioration in first-lien credit quality from acquisition financing. DLS Preferred Row 9 (alternative): for pari debt, 'the [first lien net leverage ratio] would be no greater than closing date [first lien net leverage].' PC Term Comparison line 222: 'set at equivalent closing level; no headroom other than occasionally up to 0.25x for junior lien debt.'
children.name: First Lien Ratio
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 9 (alternative: first lien ratio at closing); PC Term Comparison line 222 (leverage at closing level)

children.definition: Total net leverage ratio threshold for incurring unsecured acquisition debt on an unlimited basis. Set with more headroom than first lien ratio to reflect the subordinated position of unsecured claims. DLS Preferred Row 9 (alternative): for unsecured debt, 'the Senior [Net] Leverage Ratio/Total [Net] Leverage Ratio would be no greater than closing date Senior [Net] Leverage/Total [Net] Leverage.' PC Term Comparison: 'no headroom other than 0.25-0.50x for unsecured debt.'
children.name: Total Leverage Ratio

red_flags.market_context: Institutional expectation is total debt calculation includes all debt obligations
red_flags.text: Consolidated Total Debt or FCCR excludes certain debt types (second lien, revolver, working capital, subordinated, senior unsecured) — understates true leverage

red_flags.market_context: DLS preferred: same ratio levels as ratio debt basket, not 'no worse'
red_flags.text: Incurred Acquisition Ratio Debt with 'no worse' leverage test — allows acquisition debt without actual deleveraging

red_flags.market_context: PC market preference: Total Leverage Ratio for incurrence tests with exceptions for Aggressive UMM/BSLR
red_flags.text: Total Leverage Ratio not used for incurrence tests — First Lien or Secured Leverage used instead, masking total debt

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 9 (alternative: total leverage ratio for unsecured); PC Term Comparison line 222 (0.25-0.50x headroom for unsecured)

children.definition: Pro forma leverage ratio thresholds that gate the borrower's capacity to incur acquisition debt on an unlimited basis, mirroring the tiered ratio structure used for incremental facilities. DLS Preferred Row 9 (alternative): separate ratios by seniority — first lien net leverage for pari, secured net leverage for junior lien, total net leverage or interest coverage ratio for unsecured. The ratio tests are the same as incremental ratio capacity, but some sponsors negotiate 'no worse' prongs for acquisition debt. PC Term Comparison line 385: 'No worse and FCCR prongs typically rejected including in UMM/BSLR transactions.'
children.name: Ratio Tests
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 9 (alternative: tiered ratio structure); PC Term Comparison line 385 ('no worse' typically rejected)

children.definition: Dollar or EBITDA-percentage cap limiting the amount of incurred acquisition debt that may be held at non-loan-party subsidiaries, preventing structural seniority to the credit facility. PC Term Comparison line 383: 'Non-Guarantor Cap will generally apply in all transactions including Aggressive UMM/BSLR.' The non-guarantor cap for acquisition debt is often shared with (counted against) the general non-guarantor debt sub-limit, which creates competition between acquisition and operational non-guarantor debt capacity.

iridium.value: Shared $177.2M / 40% EBITDA; also $110.75M / 25% EBITDA cash consideration cap for non-LP entities

children.name: Non-Guarantor Cap

red_flags.market_context: Fixed basket debt must be included in leverage calculations for covenant compliance
red_flags.text: Debt incurred under fixed baskets (freebie, non-guarantor, general, acquisition) excluded from financial covenant compliance testing

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 383 (non-guarantor cap universality)

children.definition: Whether newly incurred acquisition financing debt is subject to the MFN pricing protection that would trigger a margin step-up on existing term loans if the acquisition debt yield exceeds the existing yield by more than the MFN cushion (typically 50 bps). PC Term Comparison line 237 (conservative scope): MFN applies to 'all pari debt including debt securities, IED, Ratio debt, incurred acquisition debt and any other ratio baskets.' Aggressive UMM/BSLR scope limits MFN to 'pari term loans only.' The conservative position treats acquisition debt as subject to MFN unless the outside-maturity exception applies.
children.name: MFN Applies

red_flags.market_context: PC market: very rare even in aggressive UMM/BSLR
red_flags.text: Acquisition exception to MFN — very rare even in aggressive UMM/BSLR transactions

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison lines 236-237 (MFN scope: conservative vs aggressive); DLS Preferred Row 11 (MFN 50 bps for life)

children.definition: Whether maturity date and weighted average life to maturity protections apply to incurred acquisition debt, preventing acquisition financing from maturing before the existing credit facility. PC Term Comparison line 384: 'WALM/Maturity/Inside maturity carveouts: Aggressive UMM/BSLR may not have these protections (or a cap on inside maturing debt); otherwise Clients will expect these protections.' DLS Preferred Row 9 (alternative): inside-maturity threshold and shorter-WAL threshold are separately sized dollar carveouts for debt that does not meet the maturity floor.
children.name: Maturity Constraints
children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 384 (maturity protections by segment); DLS Preferred Row 9 (alternative: inside maturity threshold)

children.definition: New debt incurred to finance a permitted acquisition. Subject to ratio tests (typically sharing levels with IED/ratio debt), non-guarantor caps, maturity/WALM limitations, and MFN protection. PC Term Comparison: 'Some Sponsors will ask for the leverage ratios to be no worse' but this is 'typically rejected including in UMM/BSLR transactions.' Distinguished from assumed acquisition debt by being newly created rather than pre-existing.
children.name: Incurred Acquisition Debt
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 alternative (ii) 'Incurred Acquisition Ratio Debt Basket'; PC Term Comparison line 385

children.definition: Carveout permitting the borrower group to assume existing indebtedness of an acquisition target without treating it as newly incurred debt, provided the debt was not entered into 'in contemplation of' the acquisition. DLS Preferred Row 79 (alternative): 'Assumed Acquisition Debt: Typically governed by same ratios, but there is no restriction on the terms of such debt so long as such debt was not incurred in contemplation of such acquisition.' The assumed debt basket addresses pre-existing target obligations that cannot be restructured as a condition to closing.
children.name: Permitted

red_flags.market_context: DLS alternative: no terms restriction but 'not incurred in contemplation' requirement still applies
red_flags.text: Assumed Acquisition Debt has no ratio requirement and no restriction on terms — open-ended debt assumption

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 (alternative: Assumed Acquisition Debt)

children.definition: Whether assumed acquisition debt is permitted without a stated dollar cap, subject only to the 'not incurred in contemplation of the acquisition' condition and pro forma ratio compliance. The uncapped formulation is standard because the assumed debt represents pre-existing obligations of the target that the borrower cannot control, and the contemplation standard provides the primary protection against sponsor engineering of assumed debt capacity.
children.name: Uncapped

red_flags.market_context: DLS alternative: no terms restriction but 'not incurred in contemplation' requirement still applies
red_flags.text: Assumed Acquisition Debt has no ratio requirement and no restriction on terms — open-ended debt assumption

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 (alternative: assumed debt governed by ratios, no term restrictions)

children.definition: Whether the assumed debt basket requires that the target's pre-existing indebtedness was 'not incurred in contemplation of' the acquisition, preventing the sponsor from arranging for the target to incur fresh debt shortly before closing to be assumed as 'existing' obligations. DLS Preferred Row 79 (alternative): 'there is no restriction on the terms of such debt so long as such debt was not incurred in contemplation of such acquisition.' The contemplation standard is the primary guardrail on assumed debt — without it, assumed debt becomes a backdoor to uncapped, term-unrestricted debt incurrence.
children.name: Contemplation Standard

red_flags.market_context: DLS alternative: no terms restriction but 'not incurred in contemplation' requirement still applies
red_flags.text: Assumed Acquisition Debt has no ratio requirement and no restriction on terms — open-ended debt assumption

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 (alternative: contemplation standard for assumed debt)

children.definition: Whether assumed acquisition debt must satisfy the same pro forma leverage ratio test as incurred acquisition debt, treating the assumption as if it were a new incurrence. DLS Preferred Row 79 (alternative): assumed acquisition debt is 'governed by same ratios' as ratio debt. When a ratio test applies, the aggregate of assumed and incurred acquisition debt cannot exceed what the borrower could incur on a combined pro forma basis, preventing leverage from exceeding ratio-based limits through the assumption of target debt.

iridium.value: Must meet same ratios as for incremental loans

children.name: Ratio Test Required

red_flags.market_context: DLS alternative: no terms restriction but 'not incurred in contemplation' requirement still applies
red_flags.text: Assumed Acquisition Debt has no ratio requirement and no restriction on terms — open-ended debt assumption

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 (alternative: assumed debt governed by same ratios)

children.definition: Dollar amount limiting the aggregate assumed acquisition debt when the credit agreement uses a fixed-dollar basket rather than an unlimited ratio-tested formulation. The fixed-cap approach provides certainty to lenders about maximum assumed debt exposure but limits the borrower's ability to acquire targets with material pre-existing leverage. Conservative credit agreements may pair a fixed cap with a ratio-tested uncapped prong, allowing the borrower to exceed the fixed cap if pro forma leverage is satisfied.
children.name: Cap Amount (If Capped)

red_flags.market_context: DLS alternative: no terms restriction but 'not incurred in contemplation' requirement still applies
red_flags.text: Assumed Acquisition Debt has no ratio requirement and no restriction on terms — open-ended debt assumption

children.definition_source: Review Template Row 26 (Incremental Amount – ratio); Review Template Row 73 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Ratio Debt – amount); Review Template Row 74 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Ratio Debt – non-guarantor cap); Review Template Row 77 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Incurred Acquisition Debt – amount); Review Template Row 78 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Incurred Acquisition Debt – non-guarantor cap); Review Template Row 122 (Negative Covenants – Available Amount – Ratio Test)

children.definition: Whether the credit agreement requires assumed acquisition debt to be refinanced or repaid within a specified period after the acquisition closes, typically 60-90 days. A refinancing requirement ensures that assumed debt is temporary — the borrower must replace it with debt incurred under the credit agreement's regular baskets (subject to standard terms, MFN, and maturity protections) rather than maintaining potentially more permissive pre-existing target debt terms indefinitely.
children.name: Refinancing Requirement

red_flags.market_context: DLS alternative: no terms restriction but 'not incurred in contemplation' requirement still applies
red_flags.text: Assumed Acquisition Debt has no ratio requirement and no restriction on terms — open-ended debt assumption

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 16 (refinancing conditions)

children.definition: Whether the non-guarantor sub-limit for assumed acquisition debt at non-loan-party target entities is shared with (counted against) the incurred acquisition debt non-guarantor cap. Shared caps create competition between assumed and incurred non-guarantor capacity, limiting aggregate structural seniority. PC Term Comparison line 383: non-guarantor caps apply universally, including to acquisition debt of all types. When caps are shared, assuming large non-guarantor target debt reduces incurred acquisition debt capacity at non-guarantor entities.
children.name: Non-Guarantor Cap Shared

red_flags.market_context: DLS alternative: no terms restriction but 'not incurred in contemplation' requirement still applies
red_flags.text: Assumed Acquisition Debt has no ratio requirement and no restriction on terms — open-ended debt assumption

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Incurred Acquisition Debt – non-guarantor cap

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 383 (non-guarantor cap universality)

children.definition: Pre-existing debt of an acquisition target that is assumed (not incurred 'in contemplation of' the acquisition). DLS Preferred: 'Typically governed by same ratios, but there is no restriction on the terms of such debt so long as such debt was not incurred in contemplation of such acquisition.' 97% of corpus has assumed debt capacity. Distinguished from incurred acquisition debt by being pre-existing target debt, with no control over its original terms.
children.name: Assumed Acquisition Debt

red_flags.market_context: DLS alternative: no terms restriction but 'not incurred in contemplation' requirement still applies
red_flags.text: Assumed Acquisition Debt has no ratio requirement and no restriction on terms — open-ended debt assumption

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 alternative (iii)

children.definition: Whether incurred and assumed acquisition debt draw from a single shared capacity pool or operate as independent baskets. When capacity is shared, a large assumed debt transaction reduces the remaining capacity for incurred acquisition financing, and vice versa. Sharing prevents the borrower from using both baskets at full capacity for the same acquisition, which would effectively double the available acquisition leverage.
children.name: Shared Capacity Pool

children.definition: Whether Limited Condition Transaction (LCT) provisions permit the borrower to test ratio-based acquisition debt capacity at the time of signing the acquisition agreement rather than at closing, providing certainty of financing. DLS Preferred Row 15: 'Borrower may elect to test any Ratios/Baskets/Conditions required to be complied with in connection with such LCA at the time of signing the definitive documentation.' LCT provisions apply to acquisition debt because acquisition financing requires certainty between signing and closing, during which borrower financials may deteriorate.
children.name: LCT Provisions
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 15 (Limited Condition Acquisition testing framework)

children.definition: Shared structural features governing both incurred and assumed acquisition debt, including leverage test levels, non-guarantor caps, limited condition acquisition testing (LCT), and coordination with incremental facility capacity. DLS Preferred Row 15 establishes LCT mechanics where borrower may elect to test ratios at signing rather than closing of the acquisition.
children.name: Shared Mechanics (Incurred + Assumed)
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 15 (LCT)

children.definition: Debt incurred or assumed 'in connection with' permitted acquisitions. Two sub-types: (1) incurred acquisition debt — new borrowings to fund acquisition consideration, subject to ratio tests; (2) assumed acquisition debt — pre-existing target company debt that continues post-acquisition, typically governed by a 'not incurred in contemplation' test. DLS Preferred Row 79: '(iii) debt incurred in connection with Permitted Acquisitions in an amount and on terms to be agreed.' PC Term Comparison: No-worse prong 'typically rejected including in UMM/BSLR.' 73% of corpus has acquisition debt capacity.

entries.description: Debt incurred to fund acquisitions (Incurred Acquisition Debt) or existing debt of acquired targets (Assumed Acquisition Debt), with distinct treatment for each.
entries.label: Indebtedness - Acquisition Debt

concept_specific_notes: [neg_cov_debt.acquisition_debt] Universal basket (9/9). Removed 'acquired' (4.3% precision) and 'acquisition' (9.1% precision) — both too noisy at document level. 'assumed in connection with' and 'existed/existing at the time' are high-precision anchors for this basket within the section.
search_strategy.fallback_escalation: Search for 'shall not incur' or 'Permitted Indebtedness' or 'incurrence of Indebtedness'. If none found, search for 'other Indebtedness' or 'aggregate principal amount' near negative covenant headings.

children.definition: Fixed dollar or EBITDA-percentage amount available at closing as the initial capacity of the Available Amount basket within the indebtedness covenant, before any builder additions accumulate. The starter provides day-one flexibility without requiring operational performance. PC Term Comparison: Aggressive UMM/BSLR starter is 40-50% EBITDA; CMM/LMM typically 5-25% EBITDA. DLS Preferred Row 86: starter is not separately identified — AA starts with retained ECF and equity contributions only.

children.definition: The portion of excess cash flow that remains after the mandatory ECF sweep prepayment and accrues into the Available Amount basket, building debt capacity over time. DLS Preferred Row 86: Available Amount grows by 'the percentage of Excess Cash Flow commencing with respect to the 20[  ] fiscal year equal to the percentage thereof that is not taken into account in calculating the Excess Cash Flow prepayment.' PC Term Comparison: 'Retained ECF should only be increased by retained percentage of ECF and not the net ECF unswept amount; de minimis deductible should not build Retained ECF.'

The 'not otherwise applied' requirement prevents the same equity dollars from simultaneously building AA capacity and curing a financial covenant default or funding contribution debt.

DLS Row 86 alternative mentions 'Incurrence of Debt and Liens' as an Available Amount usage, implying both secured and unsecured debt may be possible. PC Term Comparison Indebtedness section does not establish specific security requirements for AA debt beyond the general framework. Distinguished from ratio debt security tiers by being governed by the AA usage conditions rather than an independent leverage test.
children.name: Security & Maturity for AA Debt

children.definition: Whether the Available Amount is maintained as a single shared pool from which restricted payments, restricted debt payments, investments, and debt incurrence all draw, or whether separate AA sub-baskets are tracked independently per covenant. The single-pool approach creates competition among uses — AA capacity consumed by a dividend reduces debt capacity — while separate tracking allows each covenant's AA to operate independently, increasing total utilization. PC Term Comparison: 'Available Amount to be used for Restricted Payments, Restricted Debt Prepayments and Investments' — standard is shared across the three traditional uses.
children.name: Shared vs Separate Tracking

children.definition: Anti-double-counting guardrail requiring that equity contributions, returns on investments, and other amounts credited to the Available Amount basket have not been simultaneously applied to build capacity under any other basket (cure equity, contribution debt, or other RP/investment capacity). PC Term Comparison: 'Include not otherwise applied language throughout agreement to avoid double counting (e.g., equity contributions).' This language prevents the same dollar of equity from appearing in both the AA builder and a separate contribution debt basket or RP capacity builder.
children.name: Not Otherwise Applied Language
children.pc_term: Include 'not otherwise applied' language throughout agreement

children.definition: The coordination between Available Amount capacity used for indebtedness versus restricted payments, restricted debt prepayments, and investments. When AA is a single shared pool, using AA for debt incurrence reduces RP and investment capacity proportionally. DLS Preferred Row 86: 'Available Amount to be used for Restricted Payments, Restricted Debt Prepayments and Investments.' DLS Preferred Row 86 (alternative): AA can also be used for 'Incurrence of Debt and Liens', expanding the competition for shared capacity.

Distinguished from standalone debt baskets by having a shared pool that competes with non-debt uses.

children.definition: Debt capacity linked to the Available Amount (builder basket), a cumulative pool that grows over time through retained earnings, equity contributions, and other performance-based mechanisms. The Available Amount is a runtime accumulator, not a static definition — its value depends on the history of ECF sweeps, equity raises, and investment returns since closing. DLS Preferred Row 86: 'Incurrence of Debt and Liens' is listed as an alternative usage of the Available Amount. PC Term Comparison Available Amount section establishes starter ranges of 5-25% EBITDA for CMM/LMM and 10-50% for UMM/BSLR. Distinguished from the general basket (fixed capacity) by growing dynamically based on financial performance and capital events.

search_strategy.fallback_escalation: Search for 'shall not incur' or 'Permitted Indebtedness' or 'incurrence of Indebtedness'. If none found, search for 'other Indebtedness' or 'aggregate principal amount' near negative covenant headings.

Section 2.14/2.20 for Incremental Facility mechanics (incremental_facility basket lives there, not in neg cov section)

children.definition: Standard contribution debt allowance permitting incurrence of debt equal to 100% of cash equity contributions received after the closing date. The dollar-for-dollar structure ensures that each dollar of equity contributed generates at most one dollar of additional debt capacity. PC Term Comparison line 404: 'Aggressive UMM/BSLR: typically 100% and unsecured with outside date for incurrence.' The 100% ratio is market standard across all segments.
children.name: Standard (100%)

children.definition: Aggressive contribution debt formulation permitting debt incurrence equal to 200% of equity contributions, creating 2x leverage on each dollar contributed. This structure allows the sponsor to effectively recapitalize by injecting equity and immediately incurring twice that amount in debt, resulting in net cash extraction from the business. The 200% ratio is rare outside BSL transactions and is not contemplated in PC Term Comparison or DLS Preferred guidance.

The ratio-based formulation provides a clear mathematical relationship between equity injected and debt capacity created.

children.definition: Equity interests that qualify as true equity (not disqualified stock) for purposes of generating contribution debt capacity. Qualified equity interests must not be redeemable at the holder's option, mandatorily redeemable within 91 days of the latest facility maturity, or convertible into debt. This requirement ensures that equity generating contribution debt capacity represents permanent capital rather than quasi-debt that could be demanded back, which would leave the contribution debt outstanding without the supporting equity cushion.

A shorter window reduces the risk that contribution debt is incurred after the equity cushion has been consumed by operational losses, while a longer window provides flexibility for staged transactions.

children.definition: Whether the equity contribution and the contribution debt incurrence must occur simultaneously or substantially simultaneously, rather than permitting a lag between them. Contemporaneous incurrence prevents the scenario where equity is contributed, subsequently consumed by operations, and then contribution debt is incurred against a now-depleted equity base. This is a more protective formulation than a day-window approach.

A use-it-or-lose-it provision ensures that stale equity contributions cannot be leveraged, preventing the accumulation of latent debt capacity from historical contributions whose equity cushion may no longer exist.

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 404 (unsecured standard)

children.definition: Aggressive formulation allowing contribution debt to be secured by liens on the collateral, either on a junior lien or pari passu basis. Secured contribution debt significantly increases the risk to first-lien lenders because equity-generated debt capacity now competes for collateral value. This formulation is rare and should be flagged. KCT Cat 4 Item 12: 'Identify ability to incur debt secured by assets not part of our collateral at the borrower or guarantor level.'

children.definition: Whether liens securing contribution debt attach automatically upon incurrence of the debt without requiring a separate lien basket capacity determination or agent consent. Automatic security attachment is the most aggressive formulation because it bypasses the liens covenant's independent gate function — the borrower need not confirm that a corresponding lien basket exists. Standard practice requires separate lien permission for any secured contribution debt.

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 67 (Security); Review Template Row 143 (Second Lien Facility); Review Template Row 144 (Cushions to first lien)

children.definition: When contribution debt is permitted to be secured, the priority level at which liens may attach: pari passu (sharing first-lien collateral equally with the credit facility), junior lien (subordinated security interest), or unsecured only (no lien permitted). PC Term Comparison line 404: market standard is unsecured. If secured, junior lien is strongly preferred over pari passu because pari contribution debt directly dilutes first-lien recovery and requires a pari passu intercreditor agreement.

children.definition: Whether the liens covenant includes a dedicated basket permitting liens to secure contribution debt, or whether contribution debt security must consume capacity under the general liens basket or another existing lien permission. A dedicated lien carveout for contribution debt is aggressive because it creates additional secured debt capacity that is mechanically linked to equity contributions rather than independently capped. PC Term Comparison line 407: 'Avoid having both a general liens basket and a crossing lien to general debt basket' — the same anti-double-counting principle applies to contribution debt lien carveouts.
children.name: Dedicated Lien Carveout

Conservative structures require contribution debt to be unsecured and effectively subordinated. Distinguished from acquisition debt security (which may be pari passu) by typically being required to be unsecured.

children.definition: Requirement that contribution debt be subject to payment subordination provisions that block scheduled interest and principal payments during a payment default, bankruptcy event, or other specified default period under the senior credit facility. Payment blockage ensures that senior lenders have priority over cash flows during distress, preventing contribution debt holders from draining liquidity needed for senior debt service.
children.name: Payment Subordination

children.definition: Requirement that contribution debt be incurred at the holdings or parent level (not at the borrower or guarantor level), creating structural subordination where contribution debt holders have claims only against holdco assets after all operating entity obligations are satisfied. Structural subordination is complementary to but distinct from payment subordination — even without a subordination agreement, holdco creditors are structurally junior because operating entity assets are pledged to the credit facility.

children.definition: Requirement that contribution debt mature no earlier than 91 days after the latest maturity date of the credit facility, ensuring that contribution debt holders cannot accelerate or demand repayment before the senior credit facility matures. The 91-day buffer provides a temporal cushion preventing contribution debt maturity from triggering cross-default or cross-acceleration provisions under the credit facility during the final months before maturity.

DLS Preferred Row 86 AA also excludes 'any cure equity and equity otherwise applied.' Prevents double-counting: equity used to cure a financial covenant default cannot also generate debt capacity.

children.definition: Coordination between contribution debt and Available Amount builder. Equity contributions that build contribution debt capacity should not simultaneously build the Available Amount equity component. DLS Preferred Row 86: AA equity builder excludes 'equity otherwise applied.' PC Term Comparison: 'Include not otherwise applied language throughout agreement to avoid double counting.' Distinguished from the equity cure exclusion by addressing AA double-counting rather than cure proceeds.

Conservative structures may impose a dollar cap in addition to the ratio. Distinguished from the allowance ratio by being a hard ceiling independent of contribution size.

children.definition_source: Review Template Row 74 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Ratio Debt – non-guarantor cap); Review Template Row 78 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Incurred Acquisition Debt – non-guarantor cap)

children.definition: The aggregate structurally senior debt capacity that becomes available when multiple fixed-dollar baskets and the contribution debt basket are stacked together at the non-loan-party level. KCT Cat 2 Item 1: identify 'Structurally senior capacity includes each of the following, which may be stacked' — this includes non-guarantor sub-limits from ratio debt, acquisition debt, general debt, and contribution debt baskets. When all are additive, total non-loan-party debt capacity can materially exceed any individual basket's sub-limit.

contribution_debt_lmm.value: Capped (0-50%), must be unsecured if permitted

children.name: Structurally senior capacity (stackable components)
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 2 Item 1 (structurally senior stacking identification)

children.definition: The technique of sequencing fixed-dollar baskets (freebie, prepayment, contribution debt) with ratio-based incurrence capacity so that debt incurred under fixed baskets is excluded from the pro forma ratio calculation, allowing the borrower to incur fixed-basket debt first and then separately incur unlimited ratio-tested debt as if the fixed-basket debt did not exist. KCT Cat 2 Item 1: identify baskets 'that may be stacked, or may be reclassified to allow the incurrence of additional pari or structurally senior debt.' The contribution debt basket is particularly susceptible to stacking because it creates capacity that is independent of leverage.
children.name: Fixed-plus-ratio stacking
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 2 Item 1 (basket stacking identification); DLS Preferred Row 9 (alternative: freebie excluded from ratio calculation)

children.definition: Debt in an amount equal to a percentage of post-closing equity contributions, creating a leveraged investment mechanism for equity sponsors. DLS Preferred Row 79 alternative (iv): 'indebtedness in an amount equal to any cash, and certain other in-kind, equity contributions (other than in connection with an equity cure or other contributions that are otherwise applied to build other baskets).' PC Term Comparison: 'Aggressive UMM/BSLR: typically 100% and unsecured with outside date for incurrence.' Distinguished from available amount debt by being sized to specific equity injections rather than cumulative retained earnings. 69% of corpus has this basket, more common in larger deals.

entries.description: Debt from purchase money financing for asset acquisitions and contribution debt based on equity contributions.
entries.label: Indebtedness - Purchase Money & Contribution Debt

search_strategy.fallback_escalation: Search for 'shall not incur' or 'Permitted Indebtedness' or 'incurrence of Indebtedness'. If none found, search for 'other Indebtedness' or 'aggregate principal amount' near negative covenant headings.

children.definition: Non-guarantor sub-basket sharing capacity with ratio-based incurrence debt, so that non-guarantor debt incurred under the ratio basket counts against the aggregate non-guarantor limit. The sharing mechanism prevents the borrower from incurring the full ratio debt capacity at non-guarantor entities, which would create uncapped structural seniority. When the non-guarantor cap is shared with ratio debt, using non-guarantor ratio debt reduces the remaining capacity for non-guarantor debt under other baskets.

children.definition: Non-guarantor sub-basket sharing capacity with incremental equivalent debt, preventing IED issued at non-guarantor entities from bypassing the aggregate non-guarantor limit. PC Term Comparison line 383: non-guarantor cap applies universally including to IED. When shared, non-guarantor IED consumes capacity under both the IED basket and the aggregate non-guarantor sub-limit.

children.definition: Aggregate cap on non-guarantor debt that is shared with (counted against) one or more of the ratio debt, acquisition debt, or IED baskets, creating competition between non-guarantor capacity across basket types. Shared caps prevent the borrower from separately maximizing non-guarantor debt under each basket, which would result in aggregate structural seniority far exceeding any individual sub-limit. KCT Cat 2 Item 1: identify 'Structurally senior capacity includes each of the following, which may be stacked.'

children.definition: Non-guarantor debt capacity expressed solely as a fixed dollar amount without any EBITDA-based grower component, providing a hard ceiling that does not scale with borrower size. The dollar-only structure becomes increasingly tight as EBITDA grows, which may restrict the borrower's ability to maintain foreign subsidiary operations and local-market financing. However, it provides greater certainty to lenders about maximum structural seniority exposure.

children.definition: Complete prohibition on non-guarantor debt, requiring all restricted subsidiaries (except standard exclusions for foreign subs, CFCs, and immaterial subs) to become guarantors and pledge their assets. This is the most protective structure because it eliminates structural seniority risk entirely. The no-basket approach is rare and typically limited to LMM deals with simple domestic corporate structures.

children.definition: Treatment of domestic holding companies whose only material assets are equity interests in controlled foreign corporations (CFCs). CFC holdcos are excluded from the guarantor group because requiring them to guarantee and pledge their CFC stock beyond 65% of voting equity would trigger deemed dividend taxation under Section 956 of the Internal Revenue Code. DLS Preferred Row 67: equity pledges of first-tier non-US subsidiaries are limited to '65% of the voting and 100% of the non-voting equity interests.'

children.definition: Domestic subsidiaries falling below the materiality threshold (typically 2.5-5% of consolidated total assets or EBITDA) that are excluded from the guarantor group to avoid the administrative cost and legal expense of obtaining guarantees from entities that contribute negligible value. DLS Preferred Row 66: exclusion for subsidiaries that the Borrower and Agent 'agree that the cost of providing such guarantee is excessive in relation to the value afforded thereby.' The immaterial subsidiary threshold must be defined to prevent gaming through entity restructuring.

children.definition: Whether the borrower retains the ability to redesignate restricted subsidiaries as unrestricted (or vice versa), which can indirectly expand non-guarantor exposure by moving entities outside the restricted group entirely. Designation to unrestricted status removes the entity from the guarantor group and the collateral package, creating a more severe form of structural seniority risk than non-guarantor debt within the restricted group. PC Term Comparison line 334-343: designation conditions include EoD stopper, investment capacity, and leverage condition.

The complement of this guarantor scope defines the non-guarantor universe.

children.definition: Whether the non-guarantor debt cap applies as an aggregate limit across all non-loan-party entities combined or as a per-entity limit on each non-guarantor subsidiary individually. The aggregate cap is the standard and more protective formulation because it limits total structural seniority regardless of how many non-guarantor entities incur debt. A per-entity cap allows each non-guarantor to incur up to the full cap amount, potentially resulting in aggregate exposure that is a multiple of what an aggregate cap would permit.
children.name: Aggregate vs Per-Entity Cap

children.definition: Provision treating debt incurred at a non-loan-party subsidiary as a deemed investment by the loan party parent, consuming capacity under the investment covenant simultaneously with the indebtedness covenant. The deemed-investment treatment creates a dual gate: the borrower must have both indebtedness basket capacity and investment basket capacity to incur non-guarantor debt. This cross-covenant coordination prevents the borrower from using the non-guarantor debt basket to circumvent investment covenant restrictions on downstream transfers.

market_benchmarks.market_standard_value: Intercompany loans to NLPs deemed investments

children.definition: Provision blocking payments on intercompany debt owed by loan parties to non-loan-party subsidiaries during a specified blockage period following a default under the senior credit facility. Payment blockage prevents cash from flowing upstream from loan parties to non-guarantor subsidiaries during periods of financial distress, preserving liquidity for senior debt service.

children.definition: Requirement that intercompany debt owed by loan parties to non-loan-party subsidiaries be subordinated to the obligations under the senior credit facility, including payment blockage, standstill, and turnover provisions. PC Term Comparison line 375: 'Require that intercompany debt owed by Loan Parties to non-Loan Parties is subordinated to the PC Client debt.' This prevents double-dip scenarios where non-loan-party subsidiaries lend to loan parties and then compete with the credit facility for repayment.
children.name: Intercompany Subordination Requirements

children.definition: Requirement that a minimum percentage of the consolidated EBITDA or total assets of the borrower and its restricted subsidiaries be represented by guarantor entities, preventing the borrower from shifting value to non-guarantor subsidiaries (a process known as 'hollowing out' the guarantor group). The coverage test ensures that the guarantor group maintains a meaningful share of the enterprise value supporting the credit facility.
children.name: Guarantor Coverage Test

children.definition: Restrictions on non-loan-party subsidiaries providing guarantees of external debt (debt owed to parties outside the corporate group), which if unrestricted would allow structural seniority through non-guarantor guarantee obligations that rank ahead of the credit facility at the subsidiary level. Limits on upstream guarantees prevent non-guarantor entities from pledging their credit support to external creditors who would compete with the credit facility in enforcement.
children.name: Upstream Guarantee Limits

children.definition: Provisions preventing the borrower from moving assets to non-guarantor subsidiaries to hollow out the guarantor group. KCT Cat 4 Item 2: 'Ability to make unlimited investments in unrestricted subsidiaries without reference to baskets or ratios or any other cap.' PC Term Comparison: Chewy protection, J. Crew protections, and 'non-exclusive' for licenses to block material IP transfers to non-guarantors.

children.definition: Working capital and trade finance facilities at local commercial banks in the jurisdiction where the non-guarantor subsidiary operates, providing day-to-day operating liquidity for foreign subsidiaries. Local credit facilities are necessary because the syndicate lenders may not have the capability or willingness to provide local-currency facilities in every jurisdiction where the borrower operates.

children.definition: Asset-based lending facilities at non-guarantor subsidiaries secured by the subsidiary's own receivables, inventory, and other current assets. ABL facilities provide working capital financing collateralized by the borrowing base of the non-guarantor entity. Because ABL security is limited to the subsidiary's own assets, it does not directly encumber the credit facility's collateral package.
