children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 (alternative: non-guarantor basket)

children.definition: Debt at non-loan-party restricted subsidiaries (including foreign subsidiaries). Structurally senior to credit facility claims because non-guarantor creditors have priority over subsidiary assets before any value flows up to the borrower. DLS Preferred Row 79 alternative (x): 'a fixed-dollar basket for non-guarantor indebtedness.' PC Term Comparison: non-guarantor cap 'will generally apply in all transactions including Aggressive UMM/BSLR.' Sizing typically 10-15% of EBITDA standalone, often shared with other non-guarantor caps. Distinguished from intercompany debt (which governs intra-group flows) by covering third-party debt at non-guarantor entities.

concept_specific_keywords: Loan Party to another Loan Party
concept_specific_notes: [neg_cov_debt.intercompany] Universal basket (9/9). Fixed: replaced 'owing to'/'owing by' (3-4% precision) with 'payable to any other' which catches Arch's 'Loan Party payable to any other Loan Party' pattern. Added 'Non-Guarantor Subsidiary' for sub-basket limitations. Sleep Number uses 'Company from a Company' and 'Foreign Subsidiary by a Credit Party' — unique phrasing, covered by section-level matching.
search_strategy.fallback_escalation: Search for 'shall not incur' or 'Permitted Indebtedness' or 'incurrence of Indebtedness'. If none found, search for 'other Indebtedness' or 'aggregate principal amount' near negative covenant headings.
xref_follow: Section 1.01 for Indebtedness/Debt definition
Cross-references to ratio test / Leverage Ratio definition
Cross-references to Permitted Acquisition / Limited Condition Acquisition
Section 2.14/2.20 for Incremental Facility mechanics (incremental_facility basket lives there, not in neg cov section)

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 alternative (x); PC Term Comparison line 383

children.definition: Capital lease and purchase money capacity expressed as the greater of a fixed dollar amount and a percentage of LTM EBITDA, providing a grower mechanism that scales with borrower size. PC Term Comparison: capital lease/PM baskets are part of general basket sizing — 'Baskets will include EBITDA growers but typically tighter than syndicated deals. Aggressive UMM/BSLR: 40-50% range; CMM/LMM: 10-25/30% range.'
children.name: Greater-Of Structure

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison lines 350-352 (basket grower sizing by segment)

children.definition: Capital lease and purchase money capacity expressed solely as a fixed dollar amount, providing certainty of maximum lease exposure but not scaling with EBITDA growth. The fixed component in a greater-of structure serves as a floor ensuring minimum lease capacity regardless of EBITDA fluctuations.
children.name: Fixed Dollar Cap

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 (alternative: fixed-dollar basket for PM/capital leases)

children.definition: Capital lease and purchase money capacity expressed as a percentage of LTM EBITDA, providing a grower that scales with borrower performance. Typical sizing ranges: LMM/CMM 15-20% of EBITDA; UMM/BSL 20-25% of EBITDA. The EBITDA percentage component is subject to high water marking risk (KCT Cat 2 Item 4) if the credit agreement locks the grower at the highest EBITDA ever reported.
children.name: EBITDA Percentage

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition_source: KCT Cat 2 Item 4 (high water marking)

children.definition: Capital lease and purchase money capacity expressed solely as a fixed dollar amount without any EBITDA-based grower component. This structure becomes increasingly constraining as EBITDA grows because the basket does not scale with the business. For asset-intensive borrowers, a fixed-only cap may require amendments to accommodate increased equipment financing needs.
children.name: Fixed Dollar Only

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 (alternative: fixed-dollar basket)

children.definition: Uncapped capital lease and purchase money capacity, permitting the borrower to incur unlimited finance lease and equipment financing obligations. This is rare and aggressive because uncapped lease exposure can grow to be material relative to EBITDA, particularly for asset-heavy businesses. PC Term Comparison line 387: sale-leaseback debt is 'often uncapped' in aggressive UMM/BSLR — the same logic may extend to capital leases in the most aggressive formulations.
children.name: Unlimited

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 387 (sale-leaseback uncapped in aggressive UMM/BSLR)

children.definition: How capital lease and purchase money debt capacity is expressed within the indebtedness covenant — as a fixed dollar amount, an EBITDA percentage, a greater-of grower structure, or (rarely) uncapped. DLS Preferred Row 79 (alternative): 'a fixed-dollar basket for purchase money debt and capital leases.' The cap structure determines how much equipment and lease financing the borrower can maintain.
children.name: Cap Structure

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 (alternative: fixed-dollar basket for PM/capital leases)

children.definition: Obligations arising under lease agreements classified as capital leases under pre-ASC 842 GAAP (ASC 840), where the lessee records the leased asset and corresponding liability on its balance sheet. DLS Preferred Row 13: 'the principal portion of capital leases of Holdings and its subsidiaries' is included in Total Indebtedness. Capital lease classification under legacy GAAP required meeting specific criteria (transfer of ownership, bargain purchase option, 75% of economic life, 90% of fair value).
children.name: Capital Leases (ASC 840)

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (capital leases in Total Indebtedness definition)

children.definition: Obligations arising under lease agreements classified as finance leases under ASC 842 (effective 2019), the updated accounting standard that replaced the capital lease terminology of ASC 840. ASC 842 broadened the scope of on-balance-sheet lease obligations, which is why many credit agreements include a GAAP freeze provision to prevent the accounting change from automatically expanding the definition of Indebtedness to capture leases that were previously off-balance-sheet operating leases.
children.name: Finance Leases (ASC 842)

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (capital leases in indebtedness)

children.definition: Indebtedness incurred to finance the acquisition, construction, or improvement of specific fixed assets (equipment, machinery, fixtures), where the security interest is limited to the assets financed. DLS Preferred Row 13: Total Indebtedness includes 'purchase money indebtedness.' Purchase money debt is functionally similar to capital leases but involves borrowing from a lender rather than leasing from a lessor, with the financed asset serving as the sole collateral.
children.name: Purchase Money Obligations

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position:
Limited to debt for borrowed money capital lease obligations/purchase money debt and obligations evidenced by bonds, debentures notes and similar instruments
No cap on cash netting
No requirement to keep the unrestricted cash in deposit account subject to a control agreement [...]
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Spectrum from fixed-dollar cap (lender) to ratio-based (borrower). Market often lands on greater-of formulation.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Purchase money debt and capital leases limited to fixed-dollar basket; no EBITDA-based grower component

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (purchase money in Total Indebtedness); DLS Preferred Row 79 (alternative: PM debt basket)

children.definition: Lease arrangements structured to be treated as operating leases for accounting purposes (off-balance-sheet) but as ownership for tax purposes, providing the lessee with depreciation deductions while keeping the lease obligation off the balance sheet. Synthetic leases are relevant to the capital lease basket because a GAAP freeze may exclude them from the indebtedness definition while they still represent real economic obligations that consume the borrower's debt service capacity.
children.name: Synthetic Leases

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition: Financing provided by equipment vendors or manufacturer-affiliated finance companies to fund the acquisition of specific equipment, often structured as conditional sale agreements, chattel mortgages, or installment purchase contracts. Equipment financing obligations fall within the capital lease/purchase money basket because the financed asset serves as security. Vendor-provided financing may have more favorable terms than bank lending for equipment because the vendor retains knowledge of the equipment's residual value.
children.name: Equipment Financing

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 (alternative: PM debt basket)

children.definition: The types of obligations classified under the capital lease and purchase money debt basket within the indebtedness covenant: capital leases (pre-ASC 842 terminology), finance leases (post-ASC 842), purchase money debt, synthetic leases, and equipment financing. DLS Preferred Row 13: Total Indebtedness includes 'the principal portion of capital leases of Holdings and its subsidiaries.' The scope definition interacts with the GAAP freeze provision because ASC 842 expanded what qualifies as a finance lease.
children.name: Scope / Definitions

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Total Indebtedness: capital leases)

children.definition: Whether the credit agreement includes an operative GAAP freeze date that locks the definition of capital lease and finance lease obligations at the accounting standard in effect on a specified date (typically the closing date or the date immediately prior to ASC 842 adoption). When the freeze applies, only leases that would have been classified as capital leases under legacy GAAP are treated as indebtedness, regardless of their classification under current accounting standards.
children.name: Freeze Date Applies

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 88 (change in accounting policies)

children.definition: The specific date at which the applicable GAAP standard is frozen for purposes of classifying capital lease obligations as indebtedness. Common freeze dates include the closing date, the date immediately prior to ASC 842 adoption (January 1, 2019 for public companies; January 1, 2022 for private companies), or a negotiated fixed date. The freeze date determines which accounting rules apply when classifying leases as capital versus operating for covenant compliance purposes.
children.name: Freeze Date

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 88 (change in accounting policies)

children.definition: How the credit agreement treats the transition from ASC 840 to ASC 842 for purposes of classifying lease obligations as indebtedness. Under ASC 840, only capital leases were on-balance-sheet; under ASC 842, all leases (including many former operating leases) are recognized on the balance sheet. Without a GAAP freeze or specific ASC 842 carveout, the accounting transition would automatically expand the borrower's reported indebtedness and reduce available basket capacity for legitimate capital lease/PM financing.
children.name: ASC 842 Treatment

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 88 (accounting policies)

children.definition: Whether the credit agreement's definition of capital lease obligations is frozen at a specific GAAP standard (typically pre-ASC 842 effective date) to prevent subsequent accounting standards changes from automatically expanding what qualifies as indebtedness. Without a GAAP freeze, the adoption of ASC 842 (which brought many operating leases onto the balance sheet as finance leases) would increase reported indebtedness and potentially cause covenant breaches even though the borrower's actual economic obligations did not change.
children.name: GAAP Freeze Date

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 88 ('Change in accounting policies')

children.definition: Requirement that the security interest securing capital lease and purchase money obligations attach only to the specific assets financed or leased, rather than extending to other assets of the borrower. Asset attachment is the core structural protection for the first-lien collateral package: because capital lease/PM liens are limited to the financed equipment, they do not compete with the credit facility for recovery on the broader collateral pool. Liens securing PM debt automatically fall within the liens covenant's purchase money capital lease liens basket.

market_benchmarks.market_standard_value: Lien limited to the purchased/leased asset and proceeds

children.name: Asset Attachment

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 67 (excluded assets: purchase money security interests)

children.definition: Whether sale-leaseback transactions have a dedicated sub-basket within or alongside the capital lease/PM basket, providing a separate capacity allocation for SLB obligations. A separate SLB basket prevents sale-leaseback transactions from consuming capital lease capacity needed for operational equipment financing. PC Term Comparison line 387: 'Aggressive UMM/BSLR: Often uncapped' — the SLB sub-basket may be uncapped in aggressive deals.
children.name: Separate Sale-Leaseback Basket

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 387 (SLB uncapped in aggressive UMM/BSLR)

children.definition: Whether net cash proceeds from sale-leaseback transactions are subject to the mandatory prepayment sweep that applies to asset sale proceeds. DLS Preferred Row 70: mandatory prepayment covers '100% of net cash proceeds from all non-ordinary course asset sales and insurance/condemnation proceeds (including sale leaseback transactions).' When SLB proceeds are subject to sweep, the borrower must prepay term loans rather than retaining the cash, limiting the ability to monetize assets without deleveraging.
children.name: Subject to Asset Sale Sweep

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (mandatory prepayment: includes sale-leaseback transactions)

children.definition: Whether the lease obligation created by a sale-leaseback transaction automatically generates a lien on the leased asset without requiring separate lien basket capacity. When liens are automatic, the lien covenant's purchase money/capital lease basket covers SLB liens by default. When not automatic, the borrower must confirm that a corresponding lien permission exists under the liens covenant before completing the SLB transaction.
children.name: Automatic Lien Permission

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position:
Other Lien Baskets:
(i) liens securing debt permitted to be secured under the Ratio Debt Basket and the Incurred Acquisition Debt Basket
(ii) acquired liens (not incurred in contemplation of such acquisition, so long as such acquired liens are limited to the property acquired unless any expansion of such liens is otherwise permitted) [...]
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Spectrum from fixed-dollar cap (lender) to ratio-based (borrower). Market often lands on greater-of formulation.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position:
(i) securing indebtedness under the Credit Facilities [(including any incremental, delayed draw and refinancing facilities permitted thereunder)]
(ii) a general fixed-dollar basket
(iii) [liens incurred in connection with Permitted Acquisitions in an amount and on terms to be agreed]

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 80 (liens for sale-leaseback)

children.definition: Maximum time period after the acquisition or construction of an asset within which a sale-leaseback of that asset must be completed to qualify under the capital lease/SLB basket. The lookback period prevents the borrower from using sale-leasebacks as a general financing tool for assets that have been held for extended periods, limiting SLBs to recently-acquired or recently-constructed assets where the transaction is closer to an alternative financing method.
children.name: Lookback Period

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition: Requirement that the sale price received in a sale-leaseback transaction equal or exceed the fair market value of the asset sold, preventing the borrower from transferring asset value at a discount that would reduce the restricted group's net asset base. PC Term Comparison line 66: 'FMV Requirement: Standard in all PCLs.' FMV is typically determined by a responsible officer certificate or, for material transactions, by an independent appraisal.
children.name: Fair Market Value Requirement

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 66 (FMV requirement standard in all PCLs); DLS Preferred Row 83 (dispositions: FMV)

children.definition: Whether sale-leaseback transactions receive separate treatment within the capital lease basket, including a dedicated sub-basket, sweep interaction, and coordination with the disposition and lien covenants. Sale-leasebacks are hybrid transactions (part disposition, part financing) that require coordination across multiple covenants. PC Term Comparison lines 56-57: 'Sale-leasebacks: Typically capped other than Aggressive UMM/BSLR transactions.'
children.name: Sale-Leaseback Integration

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison lines 56-57 (sale-leaseback typically capped)

children.definition: Maximum time period after the acquisition or construction of an asset within which purchase money debt or capital lease financing must be incurred to qualify under the capital lease/PM basket rather than consuming general debt basket capacity. Standard timing requirements are 270-365 days, ensuring the financing is contemporaneous with the asset acquisition rather than a post-hoc leveraging of already-owned assets.
children.name: Timing Restrictions

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition: Pre-closing leases exempt from the capital lease cap without any separate limit, grandfathering all existing lease obligations regardless of their aggregate size. The unlimited carveout reflects the view that pre-existing leases were part of the underwritten capital structure and should not count against post-closing lease capacity. However, for borrowers with large pre-closing lease portfolios, an unlimited carveout can mean that the majority of actual lease exposure is outside the basket, reducing the basket's protective value.
children.name: Unlimited for Existing

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition: Pre-closing leases subject to a separate dollar cap that limits the grandfathered amount, ensuring existing lease exposure is not entirely exempt from the capital lease basket framework. The capped carveout is more protective than the unlimited version because it forces any pre-closing leases in excess of the cap to consume regular basket capacity, providing lenders with visibility into total lease exposure. The cap is typically set at the aggregate amount of pre-closing lease obligations on the closing date.
children.name: Capped Grandfather

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition: Grandfathering provision that permits capital lease obligations existing on the closing date to remain outstanding without consuming capacity under the capital lease/PM basket. The carveout is either unlimited (all pre-closing leases exempt) or capped at a scheduled amount. Pre-closing leases represent committed obligations that existed when lenders underwrote the credit facility, so they are typically grandfathered as part of the closing-date capital structure.
children.name: Existing Lease Carveout

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 (alternative: existing debt basket)

children.definition: Fixed dollar ceiling on the aggregate amount of purchase money indebtedness within the combined capital lease/PM basket, creating a maximum sub-allocation for equipment financing. The dollar cap may be set at or below the total basket size, with the remainder available for capital lease obligations. DLS Preferred Row 79 (alternative): 'a fixed-dollar basket for purchase money debt and capital leases.'
children.name: Dollar Cap

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 (alternative: fixed-dollar PM/capital lease basket)

children.definition: Purchase money sub-limit expressed as a percentage of LTM EBITDA rather than a fixed dollar amount, providing a grower mechanism that scales the sub-allocation with borrower size. The EBITDA-based sub-limit is more common in larger deals where equipment financing needs grow proportionally with operations.
children.name: EBITDA Percentage

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral
red_flags.text: FLNLR/SNLR only includes debt secured by liens on 'substantially all' Collateral, excluding cap leases and purchase money — understates first lien leverage

children.definition: Whether the combined capital lease/purchase money basket includes a separate sub-limit that allocates a portion of total capacity specifically to purchase money debt, preventing either category from consuming the entire basket. Sub-limits provide more granular control over the composition of capital lease versus purchase money obligations within the shared capacity pool.
children.name: Purchase Money Sub-Limit

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 (alternative: fixed-dollar basket for purchase money debt and capital leases)

children.definition: Whether capital lease obligations may be refinanced with replacement lease or purchase money financing without consuming additional basket capacity, analogous to the refinancing debt basket for credit facility obligations. Refinancing rights allow the borrower to restructure existing lease obligations (renegotiating terms, extending maturity, or changing lessors) without the new obligation being treated as a fresh incurrence that counts against the basket cap.

market_benchmarks.market_standard_value: Cap does not include Permitted Refinancings

children.name: Refinancing Rights

red_flags.market_context: Template: should include all debt secured by a lien and not limited to a lien on Collateral

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 16 (refinancing debt concept)

children.definition: Obligations under capital leases and purchase money financing, generally permitted with a cap expressed as a dollar amount or EBITDA percentage. DLS Preferred Row 79 alternative (ix): 'a fixed-dollar basket for purchase money debt and capital leases.' Market sizing: LMM/CMM 15-20% of EBITDA, UMM/BSL 20-25%. DLS Preferred Row 13: Total Indebtedness includes 'the principal portion of capital leases of Holdings and its subsidiaries' and 'purchase money indebtedness.' Distinguished from sale-leaseback debt by covering new asset acquisitions financed through leases rather than sale-and-leaseback of existing assets.

entries.description: Debt incurred through capital leases (finance leases) and sale-leaseback transactions, which can effectively increase leverage.
entries.label: Indebtedness - Capital Lease & Sale-Leaseback

concept_specific_notes: [neg_cov_debt.purchase_money] Purchase Money (9/9) and Capital Lease (9/9) are universal. Finance Lease (3/9 — Boyd, Viavi, Red Rock) is newer GAAP terminology replacing Capital Lease. Capitalized Lease (6/9) is a common variant spelling.

Include incremental equivalent debt
Other Debt Baskets:
(i) “Ratio Debt Basket”: Basket for incurring debt based on any combination of senior, secured and unsecured leverage ratio baskets and/or a fixed charge coverage ratio. This debt would be incurred “outside” our credit agreement (i.e. under a separate facility). If permitted there would need to be restrictions on (i) terms of new debt, (ii) no shorter maturity/WAL, (iii) restrictions on mandatory and voluntary prepayments, (iv) MFN protection on yield and (v) non-guarantor sub-limits. children.definition: Whether intercompany debt owed by a loan party to a non-loan-party subsidiary must be subordinated to the credit facility obligations. The subordination direction here is reversed from the more typical NLP-to-LP subordination: when a loan party borrows from a non-loan party, the non-loan-party becomes a creditor of the guarantor group, and without subordination, it would compete with the credit facility for payment from the loan party's assets.

children.definition: Generally no restriction on non-loan-party subsidiaries lending to loan parties, because upstream intercompany loans bring cash into the guarantor group and are beneficial to lenders. When a non-loan-party subsidiary lends to a loan party, the cash flows toward the collateral pool, and the non-loan-party's claim against the loan party is structurally junior to the credit facility's claim on the same assets. The NLP-to-LP direction is the reverse of the leakage concern.

children.definition: Requirement that the securitization SPV be structured as a bankruptcy-remote entity that cannot be voluntarily or involuntarily placed into bankruptcy and whose assets are insulated from the claims of the borrower's creditors. Bankruptcy remoteness is achieved through independent director requirements, limited purpose restrictions, and separateness covenants that prevent substantive consolidation with the borrower's estate.
children.name: Bankruptcy-Remote

red_flags.market_context: DLS notes: consideration should be given to permitting this as it typically allows Collateral to be moved
red_flags.text: Qualified securitization facilities permitted — allows collateral to be moved into SPV structure outside lender control

red_flags.text: Securitization facilities uncapped with no restriction on asset scope — may strip collateral into SPV structures

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 (alternative: qualified securitization facilities)

children.definition: Requirement that the transfer of receivables from the borrower to the securitization SPV constitutes a 'true sale' for legal and accounting purposes rather than a secured financing. True sale treatment ensures that the receivables are owned by the SPV and not subject to the borrower's creditors' claims, which is essential for the SPV's bankruptcy-remote status. If the transfer is recharacterized as a secured loan, the receivables remain part of the borrower's estate and the securitization collapses.

children.definition: Structural protections designed to prevent a bankruptcy court from ordering 'substantive consolidation' of the securitization SPV with the borrower's estate, which would defeat the bankruptcy-remote isolation by treating the SPV's assets as available to the borrower's creditors. Anti-consolidation protections include maintaining separate books and records, arms-length transactions, independent directors, and adequate capitalization of the SPV.
children.name: Consolidation Risk

children.definition: Structural requirements for the special purpose vehicle through which receivables securitization and factoring facilities are conducted, including bankruptcy remoteness, true sale treatment, and non-consolidation protections. The SPV structure isolates securitized assets from the borrower's bankruptcy estate, which is why securitization facilities are permitted as a separate basket outside the general debt framework.
children.name: SPV Structure

children.definition: Standard structural requirement that receivables financing is isolated from the borrower and guarantor credit group, meaning securitization investors bear the credit risk of the receivables portfolio without recourse to the borrower for shortfalls. Non-recourse treatment is the market standard because it ensures the securitization does not create hidden contingent liabilities at the borrower level. PC Term Comparison line 391: 'Avoid all-asset securitizations.'
children.name: Non-Recourse to Credit Group

children.definition: Recourse to the borrower limited to standard securitization representations, warranties, and servicing obligations that are customary in receivables financing transactions, including repurchase obligations for breached representations and servicing standard compliance. Limited recourse does not extend to credit risk on the receivables themselves, maintaining the risk-transfer purpose of the securitization.
children.name: Limited Recourse

children.definition_source: Review Template Row 128 (Limited Conditionality Transactions)

children.definition: Securitization facility structure where the originating borrower retains full repayment obligation to the securitization investors, meaning the borrower must cover any shortfalls in collections from the receivables portfolio. Full recourse defeats the risk-transfer purpose of securitization and effectively makes the facility a disguised secured borrowing rather than a true asset sale. Full recourse securitization should be treated as regular secured debt rather than as a separate securitization basket.
children.name: Full Recourse

PC Term Comparison line 390-391: 'Typically capped in all transactions. Avoid all-asset securitizations.' The recourse level determines whether the securitization truly removes risk from the borrower's balance sheet or merely repackages borrower credit risk with asset-level enhancement.

EBITDA-based caps for securitization are less common than fixed dollar caps because receivables portfolios scale with revenue rather than EBITDA, but the EBITDA grower is consistent with the general basket framework.

children.definition: Definition of what constitutes a 'qualified securitization facility.' DLS Preferred Row 79 alternative (v): 'consideration should be given to permitting this as it typically allows Collateral to be moved into these facilities.' A qualified securitization must be non-recourse (or limited recourse) to loan parties, involve a true sale of receivables to an SPV, and comply with specified structural requirements.

children.definition: Receivables securitization and factoring facilities. DLS Preferred Row 79 alternative (v): 'qualified securitization facilities: consideration should be given to permitting this as it typically allows Collateral to be moved into these facilities.' PC Term Comparison: 'Typically capped in all transactions. Avoid all-asset securitizations.' Distinguished from other asset-type baskets by involving a transfer of receivables to a special purpose vehicle, potentially removing collateral from the lender's security package.

concept_specific_notes: [neg_cov_debt.securitization] Securitization (8/9, not Red Rock). Receivables Financing/Facility (7/9, 106 hits) is broader and catches more deals. Qualified/Permitted Receivables (5/9, 80 hits) is the defined term variant. Removed 'Qualified Securitization' (0/9 — completely dead) and 'factoring' (1/9, near-dead).

children.definition: Minimum time period that the borrower must have owned or constructed the asset before a sale-leaseback transaction is permitted, preventing borrowers from acquiring assets solely for the purpose of immediately monetizing them through SLBs. The lookback period ensures SLBs are limited to genuinely owned assets rather than being used as an alternative financing mechanism.

children.definition: Requirement that the sale price received in a sale-leaseback transaction equal or exceed the fair market value of the asset sold, preventing value transfer to the SLB counterparty at the expense of the borrower's asset base. PC Term Comparison line 66: 'FMV Requirement: Standard in all PCLs.' FMV compliance is typically evidenced by a responsible officer certificate.

children.definition: Sale-leaseback proceeds that are subject to the mandatory prepayment sweep, requiring the borrower to apply net cash proceeds to prepay term loans (after deducting reasonable fees and expenses). DLS Preferred Row 70: '100% of net cash proceeds from all non-ordinary course asset sales and insurance/condemnation proceeds (including sale leaseback transactions).' When subject to sweep, SLBs function as a deleveraging mechanism.

children.definition: Period within which the borrower may reinvest sale-leaseback proceeds in assets useful in its business before the proceeds must be applied as a mandatory prepayment. DLS Preferred Row 70: '100% reinvestment right to reinvest or commit to reinvest within [6/12] months with [90/180]-day extension for committed amount.' PC Term Comparison line 283: 'Aggressive UMM/BSLR: 450/540 days plus 180; Otherwise: 360 plus 180.'

children.definition: Whether the net cash proceeds from sale-leaseback transactions must be applied to prepay term loans under the mandatory prepayment sweep, reinvested in the business within a specified period, or retained freely. DLS Preferred Row 70: mandatory prepayment covers 'all non-ordinary course asset sales including sale leaseback transactions' with reinvestment rights. The reinvestment application determines whether SLB proceeds deleverage the balance sheet or remain available for other uses.

children.definition: Coordination between the sale-leaseback basket and the asset sale/disposition covenant. The 'sale' portion of a sale-leaseback must comply with asset sale requirements (FMV, cash consideration, mandatory prepayment sweep). DLS Preferred Row 83: asset sales require 'fair market value, at least 75% cash consideration, proceeds used to prepay term loans.' PC Term Comparison notes sale-leasebacks should be covered by the asset sale sweep.

children.definition: Whether a sale-leaseback transaction creates a lien on the leased asset that requires corresponding capacity under the liens covenant's purchase money/capital lease basket. The lien interaction depends on whether the SLB is structured as a capital lease (creating a lien on the leased asset in favor of the lessor) or an operating lease (no lien). DLS Preferred Row 80 (alternative): 'liens in respect of sale leaseback transactions' is a separate lien basket.

children.definition: Obligations arising from sale-leaseback transactions where the borrower sells an asset and leases it back. DLS Preferred Row 79 alternative (vi): 'debt in connection with sale leaseback transactions.' PC Term Comparison: 'Aggressive UMM/BSLR: Often uncapped. Otherwise: capped.' Sale-leasebacks should align with disposition and lien covenants. Distinguished from capital lease debt by involving an existing asset being sold and leased back rather than a new asset being lease-financed.

children.definition: No stated dollar cap on earnout obligations. PC Term Comparison line 396: 'Aggressive UMM/BSLR: If not Indebtedness no cap.' A fixed dollar cap provides certainty to lenders about maximum earnout exposure but may not accommodate multiple acquisitions over time.

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 147 (earnout measurement: maximum possible obligation)

children.definition: Earnout capacity expressed as the greater of a fixed dollar amount and a percentage of LTM EBITDA, providing a grower mechanism that scales with borrower size. The EBITDA component ensures that earnout capacity grows proportionally as the business expands through acquisitions, accommodating larger future earnout obligations without requiring an amendment.
children.name: Dollar + EBITDA %

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: general grower structure from DLS Preferred Row 79

children.definition: How earnout obligation capacity is expressed and limited within the indebtedness covenant. Earnout caps are uniquely complex because the ultimate obligation amount is contingent on future business performance, requiring measurement at the maximum possible payout. PC Term Comparison line 147: 'earnouts should always be debt for the negative covenant (with a corresponding basket; measured at maximum possible obligation per the relevant agreement).' Cap structures range from unlimited (aggressive UMM/BSLR if earnouts are not classified as indebtedness) to fixed dollar or EBITDA-percentage limits.
children.name: Cap Structure

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 147 (earnout treatment as debt; max obligation measurement)

children.definition: Whether subordination of earnout obligations to the senior credit facility is contractually required through a written subordination agreement. PC Term Comparison line 397: standard outside aggressive deals is 'subordinated and acceptable terms.' Earnout subordination ensures that the seller's contingent claim on future business performance is structurally junior to lender claims, preventing earnout payments from competing with debt service in cash-constrained periods.
children.name: Required

red_flags.market_context: Intercreditor agreements should be negotiated forms or require Required Lender consent
red_flags.text: Admin Agent required to enter into intercreditor agreements for any permitted debt without Required Lender vote — could mandate subordination to all permitted debt

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 397 (subordination standard)

children.definition: Contractual provision establishing that earnout payments are subordinated in right of payment to the obligations under the senior credit facility, meaning that scheduled earnout payments are blocked during payment defaults, bankruptcy events, or other specified default periods. Payment subordination operates through a payment blockage notice mechanism where the agent can halt earnout distributions upon delivering notice of a default.
children.name: Payment Subordination

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 397 (subordinated terms)

children.definition: Provision preventing the earnout holder from taking enforcement action (lawsuits, judgments, liens, or acceleration) during a standstill period following a senior default. The standstill period (typically 180 days) gives the senior credit facility time to exercise its own remedies without interference from junior earnout claims. After the standstill expires, the earnout holder may pursue enforcement unless the senior facility has commenced and is diligently pursuing its own remedies.
children.name: Standstill Period

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition: Requirement that any payments or collections received by the earnout holder in contravention of the subordination provisions (whether through direct payment, set-off, enforcement proceedings, or distributions in bankruptcy) must be turned over to the senior lenders for application against the senior obligations. The turnover obligation ensures that subordination is effective even if the earnout holder receives inadvertent payments or obtains judgment liens.
children.name: Turnover Provisions

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition: Whether earnout obligations must be contractually subordinated to the senior credit facility, including payment blockage during default periods, standstill on enforcement, and turnover provisions. PC Term Comparison line 397: standard treatment outside aggressive UMM/BSLR is 'Capped, subordinated and acceptable terms.' Subordination protects first-lien lenders by ensuring that earnout payments do not drain cash needed for senior debt service during periods of financial stress.
children.name: Subordination

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 397 (standard: capped, subordinated, acceptable terms)

children.definition: Condition requiring that no event of default is continuing at the time any earnout payment is made, blocking distributions to sellers during periods of financial distress. This is the most basic payment gate and is standard across all market segments. DLS Preferred Row 84: restricted payments generally require 'no default or event of default has occurred and is continuing before or thereafter.'
children.name: No Event of Default

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 84 (RP condition: no default or EoD)

children.definition: Condition requiring pro forma compliance with the financial maintenance covenant (typically a total leverage ratio) at the time of and after giving effect to the earnout payment. This gate is more protective than the no-EoD condition because it requires affirmative compliance with a forward-looking metric rather than merely the absence of a declared default.
children.name: Financial Covenant Compliance

red_flags.market_context: Fixed basket debt must be included in leverage calculations for covenant compliance
red_flags.text: Debt incurred under fixed baskets (freebie, non-guarantor, general, acquisition) excluded from financial covenant compliance testing

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Employee Stock Repurchases

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 86 (AA usage conditions: 'pro forma compliance with Financial Performance Covenants')

children.definition: Pro forma leverage test requiring that after giving effect to the earnout payment, the borrower's total net leverage ratio does not exceed a specified threshold (typically at or inside closing leverage). This condition is more restrictive than financial covenant compliance when the threshold is set below the covenant level. PC Term Comparison lines 94-99: leverage conditions for Available Amount usage range from closing total leverage (aggressive UMM/BSLR) to 0.75-1.0x inside closing leverage (CMM/LMM).
children.name: Leverage Ratio Test

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison lines 94-100 (AA leverage conditions by segment)

children.definition: Condition requiring minimum unrestricted cash on hand and/or availability under the revolving credit facility after giving effect to the earnout payment, ensuring that the borrower retains adequate liquidity for ongoing operations after making the distribution. Liquidity tests complement leverage-based gates by providing a cash-flow-based protection that captures near-term payment capacity rather than balance-sheet leverage.
children.name: Minimum Liquidity

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 82 (permitted acquisitions: 'availability under the Revolving Facility plus Unrestricted Cash not less than an amount to be agreed')

children.definition: Aggressive formulation where earnout payments are permitted without any preconditions — no EoD blocker, no leverage test, no liquidity requirement. PC Term Comparison line 396: 'Aggressive UMM/BSLR: If not Indebtedness no cap.' When earnouts are classified as indebtedness, the absence of payment conditions allows cash to flow to sellers even during financial distress, directly competing with senior debt service.
children.name: No Conditions

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 396-397 (aggressive: uncapped/no conditions vs standard: capped/subordinated)

children.definition: Conditions precedent that must be satisfied before the borrower may make earnout payments, functioning as independent gates that operate alongside (and in addition to) any subordination provisions. Payment conditions may include absence of events of default, pro forma financial covenant compliance, leverage tests, and/or minimum liquidity. These gates provide lender protection even when the earnout is not formally subordinated.
children.name: Payment Conditions

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 84 (RP payment conditions: 'no default or event of default')

children.definition: Requirement that earnout obligations arise solely in connection with a permitted acquisition, preventing the borrower from using the earnout basket for deferred payment obligations unrelated to acquisition activity. The acquisition nexus ensures that earnout capacity is tied to the borrower's M&A program and does not become a general-purpose deferred payment mechanism.
children.name: Acquisition Nexus

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 82 (permitted acquisitions framework)

children.definition: Requirement that earnout obligations have a stated maturity no earlier than 91 days after the latest maturity date of the credit facility, preventing earnout payments from coming due before or contemporaneously with the facility's final maturity. The 91-day buffer prevents earnout maturity from triggering cross-default or cross-acceleration provisions and ensures earnout holders cannot demand payment ahead of senior lenders. PC Term Comparison line 394 (CMM/LMM seller debt terms): 'later maturity.'
children.name: Maturity Requirement

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 394 (CMM/LMM seller debt: later maturity)

children.definition: Requirement that earnout obligations be measured at the maximum possible payout under the earnout agreement at the time of incurrence for purposes of testing basket capacity, rather than the expected or probable payment amount. PC Term Comparison line 147: 'measured at maximum possible obligation per the relevant agreement.' Maximum measurement is conservative because it captures the full potential exposure even though actual payouts are typically below maximum, ensuring that basket capacity is not exhausted by higher-than-expected performance.
children.name: Measurement Basis

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 147 (earnout measurement: maximum possible obligation)

children.definition: Contingent purchase price obligations (earn-outs) payable if an acquisition target meets specified performance targets. PC Term Comparison: 'earnouts should always be debt for the negative covenant (with a corresponding basket; measured at maximum possible obligation per the relevant agreement) and debt for the leverage ratios if due and payable or alternatively past due by more than 5/30 days.' Aggressive UMM/BSLR: 'If not Indebtedness no cap.' Distinguished from seller notes (which are fixed obligations) by being contingent on future performance.
children.name: Earnout Basket

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison lines 147, 396

children.definition: Seller note capacity expressed as the greater of a fixed dollar amount and a percentage of LTM EBITDA, providing a grower mechanism that scales with borrower size. The dollar component provides a floor for smaller borrowers while the EBITDA percentage ensures the basket grows proportionally as the business expands through acquisitions that generate seller note obligations.
children.name: Dollar + EBITDA %

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: general grower structure from DLS Preferred Row 79

children.definition: Single aggregate capacity pool covering both earnout obligations and seller financing notes, with total outstanding deferred purchase price obligations counted against a shared limit. Shared baskets prevent double-counting but create competition between earnout and seller note capacity — a large earnout commitment reduces available seller note capacity and vice versa.
children.name: Shared with Earnout

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 147 (earnout as debt)

children.definition: Seller note capacity expressed solely as a fixed dollar amount without an EBITDA-based grower component. A fixed-only cap provides certainty to lenders but may become constraining as the borrower grows through acquisitions that generate seller note obligations, potentially requiring an amendment to accommodate larger transactions.
children.name: Dollar Only

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition: Whether seller notes are permitted without a stated dollar cap, relying solely on subordination protections to mitigate the risk of unlimited deferred purchase price obligations. The unlimited formulation is aggressive because it allows the borrower to defer acquisition consideration without limit, creating potentially material subordinated obligations. PC Term Comparison line 397: standard treatment is 'capped, subordinated and acceptable terms' — unlimited formulations deviate from this standard.
children.name: Unlimited

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 397 (standard: capped and subordinated)

children.definition: How seller note capacity is expressed and limited within the indebtedness covenant. Unlike earnout caps where the obligation is contingent, seller note caps apply to a fixed principal amount. PC Term Comparison line 393-394: seller debt is 'Typically capped in all transactions. CMM/LMM: may require subordination terms and other acceptable terms (not cash pay, no covs, later maturity; at Holdco).' Seller note caps are typically expressed as a dollar amount, dollar-plus-EBITDA grower, or shared with earnout capacity.
children.name: Cap Structure

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison lines 393-394 (seller debt: capped, subordination terms)

children.definition: Requirement that all interest on seller notes be paid in kind (capitalized and added to principal) rather than paid in cash, ensuring that no cash leaves the restricted group for seller note interest service. PC Term Comparison line 394 (CMM/LMM seller debt): 'not cash pay.' PIK-only interest preserves cash flow for senior debt service and operations while still compensating the seller for the time value of deferred consideration.
children.name: PIK Only

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 394 (seller debt: not cash pay)

children.definition: Formulation permitting cash interest payments on seller notes, subject to conditions such as absence of default, pro forma leverage compliance, or subordination payment blockage provisions. Cash interest on seller notes is more aggressive than PIK-only because it creates regular cash outflows to the seller that compete with senior debt service. Cash pay is typically permitted only in aggressive UMM/BSLR transactions where seller notes carry market-rate terms.
children.name: Cash Interest Permitted

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 394 (CMM/LMM: not cash pay implies cash pay is aggressive)

children.definition: Maximum permitted interest rate on seller notes, expressed as either a fixed rate cap or a spread above a benchmark rate. Rate caps prevent sellers from negotiating above-market interest rates that would increase the all-in cost of the acquisition financing and create disproportionate cash outflows (when cash interest is permitted) or rapid principal accretion (when PIK). Rate caps are more common in CMM/LMM transactions where seller notes carry more restrictive terms.
children.name: Interest Rate Cap

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 394 (seller debt acceptable terms)

children.definition: Restrictions on how interest on seller notes may be paid — cash interest, payment-in-kind (PIK), or hybrid structures. PC Term Comparison line 394 (CMM/LMM): seller debt should be 'not cash pay' — PIK-only interest is the conservative standard because it prevents cash outflows to sellers that compete with senior debt service. The interest terms interact with the restricted debt payment covenant, as cash interest on seller notes may constitute a restricted junior debt payment.
children.name: Interest Terms

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 394 (CMM/LMM seller debt: not cash pay)

children.definition: Mandatory requirement that seller financing notes be subordinated to the senior credit facility obligations through a written subordination agreement in form and substance satisfactory to the administrative agent. PC Term Comparison line 394 (CMM/LMM): 'may require subordination terms and other acceptable terms.' The subordination agreement governs payment blockage, standstill, turnover, and inter-creditor mechanics between the seller and the credit facility lenders.
children.name: Required

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 394 (seller debt subordination requirement)

children.definition: Provision blocking all payments (principal, interest, and other amounts) on seller notes during a specified payment blockage period following a default or event of default under the senior credit facility. Payment blockage ensures that cash is preserved for senior debt service during periods of financial distress rather than flowing to sellers. The blockage typically extends for 179 days following delivery of a payment blockage notice by the agent.
children.name: Payment Blockage

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 394 (seller debt subordination terms)

children.definition: Requirement that seller notes mature no earlier than 91 days after the latest maturity date of the senior credit facility, ensuring sellers cannot demand repayment before or contemporaneously with the facility's final maturity. PC Term Comparison line 394 (CMM/LMM): seller debt requires 'later maturity.' The 91-day buffer is standard to prevent seller note maturity from triggering cross-default under the credit facility during the final months before the facility matures.
children.name: Maturity Extension

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 394 (seller debt: later maturity)

children.definition: Depth of subordination required for seller notes issued in connection with permitted acquisitions, governing whether payment subordination, structural subordination, or both are required. PC Term Comparison line 394 (CMM/LMM): seller debt 'may require subordination terms and other acceptable terms (not cash pay, no covs, later maturity; at Holdco).' The comprehensive subordination package (payment blockage, standstill, turnover, later maturity, holdco-level) provides maximum protection for senior lenders.
children.name: Subordination

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 394 (CMM/LMM seller debt subordination package)

children.definition: Fixed-amount deferred purchase price notes issued to sellers as part of acquisition consideration. CMM/LMM: 'may require subordination terms and other acceptable terms (not cash pay, no covs, later maturity; at Holdco)' (PC Term Comparison). Distinguished from earn-outs (which are performance-contingent) by having a fixed payment obligation. Distinguished from acquisition debt (which is third-party financing) by being seller-financed.
children.name: Seller Notes Basket

red_flags.market_context: PC market: always debt for negative covenant with basket, measured at maximum possible obligation
red_flags.text: Earnouts not treated as Indebtedness in non-UMM/BSLR deals — should always be debt for negative covenant with corresponding basket

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison lines 393-394

children.definition: Deferred purchase price obligations, seller financing notes, and earn-out payments from acquisitions. PC Term Comparison: 'earnouts should always be debt for the negative covenant (with a corresponding basket; measured at maximum possible obligation per the relevant agreement).' Aggressive UMM/BSLR: 'If not Indebtedness, no cap.' CMM/LMM: 'Capped, subordinated and acceptable terms.' Distinguished from acquisition debt (which funds the purchase) by representing deferred consideration that remains payable post-closing.

children.definition: Principal amount of the debt being refinanced that forms the baseline for the refinancing debt cap. DLS Preferred Row 16: 'Refinancing Debt cannot exceed the amount of debt being refinanced, plus fees, accrued interest, expenses, etc in connection with such refinancing.' The outstanding principal is the starting point of the cap calculation, ensuring that refinancing does not generate additional debt capacity.

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position:
Permit refinancing (in whole or in part) of the credit facility with senior secured, unsecured or subordinated notes outside the credit facility
Inside maturity date threshold of $[         ]

Market terms
No MFN protection [...]
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: MFN protection for life (lender) vs no MFN (borrower). Market typically has sunset (12-24 months). | Strict maturity floors (lender) vs inside-maturity thresholds (borrower). Market allows limited inside-maturity amounts. | Pro rata sharing (lender) vs flexible waterfall (borrower). Market standard: mandatory prepayments pro rata; voluntary may be flexible.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position:
Permit refinancing of the Credit Facility, in whole or in part with one or more new credit facilities under the credit agreement (“Refinancing Debt”); provided that
(i) Refinancing Debt cannot exceed the amount of debt being refinanced, plus fees, accrued interest, expenses, etc in connection with such refinancing, [...]

children.definition: Prepayment premiums, make-whole amounts, and call protection fees incurred in connection with the refinancing that are permitted to be added to the refinancing debt principal cap. These costs are a necessary consequence of early retirement of the refinanced debt, particularly for term loans with hard call protection (DLS Preferred Row 69: '102/101/par; hard call'). Without this component, borrowers would need separate basket capacity to fund redemption premiums.

children.definition: A fixed-dollar or percentage buffer above the sum of outstanding principal, accrued interest, premium, and fees that provides additional headroom in the refinancing debt cap. Some credit agreements include a modest cushion (typically 1-5% of refinanced principal) to cover administrative rounding differences and timing gaps between commitment and funding. An excessive cushion creates incremental debt capacity disguised as refinancing.

children.definition: Market-standard requirement that refinancing debt mature no earlier than the maturity date of the debt being refinanced, preventing the borrower from shortening the maturity profile through serial refinancings. DLS Preferred Row 16: 'Refinancing Debt cannot mature inside the debt being refinanced.' This protection ensures that refinancing extends or maintains the original repayment timeline rather than accelerating it, which would increase near-term repayment pressure.

children.definition: Aggressive formulation where refinancing debt is not subject to a maturity floor, permitting the borrower to refinance long-dated debt with shorter-maturity replacement debt. This creates the risk that refinancing debt matures before the credit facility, effectively making it senior in the repayment waterfall. DLS Preferred Row 16 (alternative): 'Inside maturity date threshold of $[  ]' — the alternative permits inside-maturity refinancing within a dollar-capped threshold.

children.definition: Dollar-capped carveout permitting a limited amount of refinancing debt to mature before the maturity date of the debt being refinanced. DLS Preferred Row 16 (alternative): 'Inside maturity date threshold of $[  ].' The inside-maturity threshold provides flexibility for smaller refinancings while maintaining the general maturity floor for the bulk of refinanced debt. PC Term Comparison line 248: 'Avoid inside maturity exception other than customary bridges and escrow arrangements.'

market_benchmarks.typical_value: 50-100% EBITDA of inside-maturing debt allowed in aggressive deals

children.definition: Requirement that refinancing debt have a weighted average life to maturity no shorter than the remaining WALM of the debt being refinanced, preventing accelerated amortization that would shorten the effective maturity despite a nominal later maturity date. DLS Preferred Row 16: 'Refinancing Debt cannot have a shorter weighted average life to maturity than the debt being refinanced.' WALM protection complements the maturity floor by preventing front-loaded amortization schedules from circumventing the maturity date constraint.

children.definition: Requirement that refinancing debt be at the same or junior priority level as the debt being refinanced, preventing the borrower from using refinancing to create debt that is senior to the credit facility. DLS Preferred Row 16: 'Refinancing Debt must be secured only by the Collateral and on a pari passu basis with the debt being refinanced.' The alternative permits pari or junior lien basis or unsecured refinancing. Refinancing into senior-priority debt would constitute an up-tiering event.

children.definition: Whether junior lien or unsecured debt may be refinanced with pari passu first-lien debt, effectively upgrading the priority of the refinanced amount. This creates an up-tiering risk where existing first-lien lenders face additional pari claims. Standard practice prohibits refinancing from junior to pari unless the ratio test for first-lien debt is separately satisfied and the refinancing debt is subject to a first-lien intercreditor agreement. PC Term Comparison line 441: 'Do not permit jr debt to be refinanced with senior debt; check Permitted Refinancing definitions and baskets.'
children.name: Junior to Pari Permitted

This prevents the borrower from using refinancing to create newly-secured debt that would encumber previously unencumbered assets, which would reduce unencumbered asset value available to unsecured creditors.

children.definition: Which debt is eligible for refinancing under this basket. DLS preferred: refinancing of the credit facility only. Alternative: 'Permit refinancing (in whole or in part) of the credit facility with senior secured, unsecured or subordinated notes outside the credit facility.' Distinguished from the principal cap (which governs size) by governing what types of existing debt can be replaced.

Standard: successive refinancings permitted subject to the same structural protections. Creates a chain of debt that must maintain the original maturity/WALM/seniority floor at each step.

market_benchmarks.market_standard_value: Permitted — refinancing of refinancing is standard

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 16

children.definition: Permission to refinance existing credit facility debt with new debt under the credit agreement ('Refinancing Debt'). DLS Preferred Row 16: refinancing permitted in whole or in part, subject to: (i) cannot exceed amount being refinanced plus fees/expenses, (ii) cannot mature inside, (iii) cannot have shorter WALM, (iv) terms no more favorable, (v) subject to MFN, (vi) secured only by collateral on pari passu basis, (vii) incurred only by borrower and guaranteed only by guarantors, (viii) must share pro rata or less than pro rata. Learning Material: 'Unlike incremental facilities, a refinancing facility is not subject to MFN pricing provisions because refinancing is not a leveraging event.' Distinguished from incremental facilities by not adding new debt — it replaces existing obligations.

entries.description: Debt incurred to refinance existing permitted debt with constraints on principal, maturity, priority, and collateral.
entries.label: Indebtedness - Refinancing Debt

entries.description: Provisions governing the incurrence of refinancing debt to replace existing permitted indebtedness, with constraints on principal amount, maturity, priority, and collateral.
entries.label: Limitation on Indebtedness - Refinancing Debt
