children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 16; Learning Material line 1580

children.definition: Requirement that hedging transactions be entered into for bona fide business purposes (risk management rather than speculation), limiting the borrower's hedging to transactions that hedge actual exposure to interest rate, currency, or commodity price fluctuations arising from its operations or debt. DLS Preferred Row 88: negative covenants include 'Speculative hedging' prohibition. The non-speculative requirement prevents the borrower from using the hedging basket to engage in proprietary trading.
children.name: Non-Speculative Requirement
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 88 (prohibition on speculative hedging)

children.definition: Restriction requiring that the hedging counterparty be a current lender under the credit facility or an affiliate of a current lender at the time the hedging arrangement is entered into. This ensures that the hedging provider is part of the lending syndicate and subject to the intercreditor arrangements governing shared collateral and payment waterfall. Lender-required counterparty restrictions are the bank-preferred standard in private credit.
children.name: Must Be Lender or Affiliate
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 78 (interest rate protection as affirmative covenant)

children.definition: Qualification providing that the counterparty only needs to be a lender or lender affiliate at the time the hedging arrangement is entered into, rather than maintaining lender status throughout the life of the hedge. If the counterparty subsequently assigns its loans and ceases to be a lender, the hedging arrangement remains in compliance. This practical accommodation reflects that hedging contracts have long tenors and cannot be easily terminated if the counterparty exits the lending syndicate.
children.name: Lender at Time of Entry

children.definition: Whether the borrower may enter hedging arrangements with counterparties that are not lenders or lender affiliates, expanding the universe of potential hedging providers. Third-party hedging is more common in larger deals where the borrower may need specialized hedging products (commodity hedges, cross-currency swaps) that syndicate lenders cannot provide. When third-party counterparties are permitted, their hedging obligations are typically unsecured and do not share in the collateral package.
children.name: Third-Party Counterparties
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 88 (speculative hedging prohibition)

children.definition: Restrictions on the counterparties with whom the borrower may enter into hedging arrangements, typically requiring that the counterparty be a lender under the credit facility, an affiliate of a lender, or (in some cases) any creditworthy financial institution. The counterparty restriction ensures that hedging obligations remain within the lender group, allowing them to share in the collateral and participate in the intercreditor waterfall.
children.name: Counterparty Restrictions
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 88 (speculative hedging); DLS Preferred Row 78 (interest rate protection covenant)

children.definition: Hedging obligations owed to a lender or lender affiliate that share in the collateral package on a pari passu basis with the credit facility obligations, benefiting from the same security interest and priority position. Secured hedging with lender counterparties is standard because it aligns the hedging provider's recovery interest with their lending interest, ensuring consistent economic incentives in enforcement scenarios.
children.name: Secured (with Lender Counterparties)
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 67 (all assets security)

children.definition: Requirement that hedging obligations owed to non-lender counterparties remain unsecured, preventing third-party hedging providers from obtaining liens on the collateral that would dilute recovery for the credit facility lenders. This distinction preserves the collateral package for the lending syndicate while still permitting the borrower to access hedging services from specialized non-lender providers.
children.name: Unsecured (Non-Lender)

children.definition: Whether hedging obligations are secured by the same collateral package as the credit facility and rank pari passu in the payment waterfall with the term loan and revolving obligations. Secured hedging obligations benefit from the collateral pool in enforcement, but they also dilute the recovery available to term loan lenders. The security treatment typically depends on whether the hedging counterparty is a lender or third party.
children.name: Secured vs Unsecured
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 67 (security: all assets of loan parties)

children.definition: Whether the credit agreement includes any stated cap on the notional amount of hedging arrangements. Notional caps are more common in private credit (LMM/CMM) where lenders have greater control over borrower activities and more limited hedging needs. In larger deals (UMM/BSLR), notional caps may be absent, relying solely on the non-speculative requirement to limit hedging exposure.
children.name: Has Notional Cap
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 88 (speculative hedging)

children.definition: Fixed dollar ceiling on the aggregate notional amount of all outstanding hedging arrangements entered into by the borrower and its restricted subsidiaries. The notional cap may be set as a multiple of the borrower's outstanding funded debt (e.g., 110% of term loan principal) to ensure hedging does not exceed the underlying interest rate or currency exposure.
children.name: Notional Cap Amount
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 73 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Ratio Debt – amount); Review Template Row 74 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Ratio Debt – non-guarantor cap); Review Template Row 77 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Incurred Acquisition Debt – amount); Review Template Row 78 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Incurred Acquisition Debt – non-guarantor cap)

children.definition: Notional cap expressed as a percentage of the underlying exposure being hedged rather than as an absolute dollar amount, ensuring that hedging positions scale proportionally with the borrower's actual risk exposure. For interest rate hedging, the cap might be 100% of outstanding floating-rate debt; for commodity hedging, a percentage of annual commodity consumption. Percentage-based caps automatically adjust as the underlying exposure changes.
children.name: Percentage of Underlying
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 78 (interest rate protection)

children.definition: Whether the credit agreement imposes a cap on the aggregate notional amount of hedging arrangements that the borrower may maintain, preventing the borrower from entering into hedging positions that exceed the underlying exposure being hedged. Notional limits are a secondary protection to the non-speculative requirement — even if the hedge is for a bona fide business purpose, an uncapped notional amount could result in hedging exposure that is disproportionate to the underlying risk.
children.name: Notional Amount Limitation
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 88 (speculative hedging prohibition — notional limits complement non-speculative requirement)

children.definition: Requirement that hedging arrangements be documented under an ISDA (International Swaps and Derivatives Association) master agreement, which provides standardized terms for netting, early termination, credit support, and dispute resolution. The ISDA master agreement is the market-standard documentation framework that enables close-out netting and provides legal certainty regarding the enforceability of hedging obligations in bankruptcy.
children.name: ISDA Master Agreement Required

children.definition: Whether mutual hedging obligations between the borrower and each counterparty are netted to a single payment obligation upon early termination, reducing gross exposure to the net mark-to-market value. Close-out netting is critical for determining the borrower's actual hedging exposure because the net amount (not the notional) represents the true economic obligation. Without netting, each hedging transaction would be a separate claim in bankruptcy.
children.name: Close-Out Netting

children.definition: Requirements governing close-out netting provisions and master agreement documentation for hedging arrangements. Close-out netting allows the borrower and counterparty to net their mutual hedging obligations to a single amount upon termination, reducing gross exposure. ISDA master agreements provide the standard framework for netting, early termination, and credit support, and are typically required for all hedging transactions.
children.name: Netting / ISDA

children.definition: Interest rate hedging instruments — swaps, caps, floors, and collars — that manage the borrower's exposure to floating-rate interest cost on its variable-rate debt. DLS Preferred Row 78: affirmative covenants include 'interest rate protection,' requiring the borrower to maintain hedging on a specified portion of its floating-rate debt. Interest rate swaps (fixing SOFR) are the most common hedging instrument in leveraged finance.
children.name: Interest Rate Hedging
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 78 (interest rate protection covenant)

children.definition: Currency hedging instruments — foreign exchange forwards, options, and cross-currency swaps — that manage the borrower's exposure to exchange rate fluctuations from foreign-currency-denominated revenues, costs, or intercompany transactions. Currency hedging is more relevant for borrowers with material international operations where FX volatility can affect EBITDA and debt service capacity.
children.name: Currency Hedging
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 88 (speculative hedging prohibition)

children.definition: Commodity hedging instruments — futures, forwards, swaps, and options — that manage the borrower's exposure to raw material and energy price fluctuations arising from its manufacturing, distribution, or resource-extraction operations. Commodity hedging is industry-specific and most relevant for borrowers in sectors with material input cost volatility (chemicals, food processing, energy, metals). The non-speculative requirement is particularly important for commodity hedging because speculative commodity positions can generate large mark-to-market losses.
children.name: Commodity Hedging
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 88 (speculative hedging prohibition)

children.definition: Categories of hedging transactions that the borrower is permitted to enter into under the indebtedness covenant, typically limited to interest rate, currency, and commodity hedging instruments. Each hedging type addresses a specific financial risk arising from the borrower's operations or debt structure. DLS Preferred Row 88: negative covenants include 'Speculative hedging' prohibition, implying that all permitted hedging must correspond to actual business risk.
children.name: Hedging Types
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 88 (speculative hedging prohibition)

children.definition: Permitted hedging obligations, typically including interest rate swaps, currency hedges, and commodity hedges. DLS Preferred Row 88: 'Speculative hedging' listed as a prohibited activity under Other Negative Covenants, implying hedging must be non-speculative. DLS Row 67: hedges/cash management can be secured if provided by agent, lenders, or their affiliates. DLS Row 78 affirmative covenant: '(xxii) interest rate protection.' Distinguished from cash management obligations (which cover banking services) by governing derivative financial instruments used to manage interest rate, currency, or commodity risk.

concept_specific_notes: [neg_cov_debt.hedging_swap] Universal basket (9/9). Every deal permits hedging/swap obligations as a separate basket within the Indebtedness section. Typically short — 'Indebtedness in respect of Hedge Agreements' or 'Swap Obligations'. The defined terms 'Hedge Agreement' and 'Swap Agreement' are in Section 1.01.
search_strategy.fallback_escalation: Search for 'shall not incur' or 'Permitted Indebtedness' or 'incurrence of Indebtedness'. If none found, search for 'other Indebtedness' or 'aggregate principal amount' near negative covenant headings.
xref_follow: Section 1.01 for Indebtedness/Debt definition
Cross-references to ratio test / Leverage Ratio definition
Cross-references to Permitted Acquisition / Limited Condition Acquisition
Section 2.14/2.20 for Incremental Facility mechanics (incremental_facility basket lives there, not in neg cov section)

lmm.structure: Non-speculative, must be with lender or affiliate
Non-speculative, must be with lender or affiliate

children.name: Hedging Obligations

red_flags.rationale: Allows speculative derivatives creating leveraged exposure
Secured obligations to parties outside syndicate

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 88 (speculative hedging prohibition), Row 67, Row 78 (xxii)

children.definition: Fixed dollar ceiling on the aggregate face amount of outstanding letters of credit, set as a sub-allocation of the total revolving commitment. DLS Preferred Row 7: '$[  ] ("Letter of Credit Sublimit"). The aggregate face amount of outstanding letters of credit issued by any Letter of Credit Issuer at any time shall not exceed the Letter of Credit Sublimit.'
children.name: Dollar Amount
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 7 (LC sublimit definition)

children.definition: Letter of credit sublimit expressed as a percentage of the total revolving credit facility commitment rather than a fixed dollar amount, allowing the LC sublimit to automatically adjust when the revolving facility increases (through incremental commitments) or decreases (through permanent commitment reductions). This formulation is less common than fixed-dollar sublimits but provides flexibility in deals with accordion features.
children.name: % of Revolver

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position:
Availability at closing not to exceed $[        ] which will be used to (1) pay the acquisition costs and (2) finance ordinary course working capital needs and working capital adjustments under the Acquisition Agreement
Availability on the Closing Date (a) unlimited amounts to finance any OID and/or upfront fees resulting from the exercise of any market flex [only applicable for deals where has pricing flex], (b) no more than $[         ] to finance the Transactions and related fees and expenses (c) unlimited to finance any Closing Date working capital needs [subject to diligence and needs of the Borrower], and (d) unlimited to replace, backstop or cash collateralize existing letters of credit [subject to diligence and needs of the Borrower]. [...]
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market landing between lender-preferred and borrower-aggressive positions; specific terms deal-dependent.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position:
$[         ]

Maturity: [   ] years

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 7 (LC sublimit structure); DLS Preferred Row 9 (accordion including revolving increases)

children.definition: Maximum aggregate face amount of letters of credit that may be issued under the revolving credit facility, functioning as a sub-allocation within the total revolving commitment. DLS Preferred Row 7: Letters of Credit sublimit is separately sized and 'The face amount of any outstanding letter of credit will reduce availability under the Revolving Facility on a dollar-for-dollar basis.'
children.name: LC Sublimit
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 7 (Letters of Credit sublimit and availability reduction)

children.definition: Designation of which lenders within the syndicate may serve as letter of credit issuers (fronting banks), bearing the direct credit exposure to LC beneficiaries until revolving lenders fund their pro rata participations. PC Term Comparison line 202-203: 'Confirm who LC issuer will be. Clients often contract it out to third parties so LC Issuer definition may need to reflect that.'
children.name: Issuing Bank
children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison lines 202-203 (LC issuer identification); DLS Preferred Row 7 (LC issuer framework)

children.definition: Whether the borrower has the right to designate a replacement letter of credit issuer if the current issuing bank declines to issue, renew, or extend a letter of credit. Replacement rights ensure the borrower's access to LC capacity is not dependent on a single fronting bank's willingness to issue. The replacement issuer must typically be acceptable to the administrative agent.
children.name: Replacement Right
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 7 (LC issuer framework)

children.definition: Maximum aggregate face amount of letters of credit that any single issuing bank may have outstanding at any time, preventing concentration of fronting risk with one lender. DLS Preferred Row 7: 'The aggregate face amount of outstanding letters of credit issued by any Letter of Credit Issuer at any time shall not exceed the Letter of Credit Sublimit.' The per-issuer limit is typically equal to the LC sublimit when there is a single issuer, or a fraction when multiple issuers are designated.
children.name: Per-Issuer Limit
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 7 (per-issuer exposure cap)

children.definition: Framework governing which lenders may serve as letter of credit issuers (fronting banks), the mechanics of lender participation in issued LCs, and the borrower's right to replace fronting banks. DLS Preferred Row 7: 'The Revolving Lenders will be obligated to acquire participations in each letter of credit, pro rata in accordance with their commitments.' Fronting risk is borne by the issuing bank until revolving lenders fund their participations.
children.name: Fronting Bank Provisions
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 7 (LC fronting and participation mechanics)

children.definition: Financial standby letters of credit that guarantee the borrower's payment obligations to a third-party beneficiary, functioning as a credit enhancement. Standby LCs are drawn only upon default by the borrower on the underlying obligation, making them contingent liabilities. They are the most common LC type in leveraged finance and are universally included in the LC sublimit.
children.name: Standby LCs
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 7 (standby letters of credit)

children.definition: Documentary trade letters of credit (commercial LCs) that facilitate international trade transactions by guaranteeing payment to a seller upon presentation of conforming shipping documents. Commercial LCs are transaction-specific and self-liquidating, as they are drawn when goods are shipped and the borrower reimburses the drawing from proceeds of the underlying sale. DLS Preferred Row 7: trade letters of credit are permitted 'if acceptable to the Letter of Credit Issuer.'
children.name: Commercial / Trade LCs
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 7 (trade LCs subject to issuer consent); PC Term Comparison line 202-203

children.definition: Performance-related letters of credit that guarantee the borrower's completion of contractual obligations (construction, service delivery, regulatory compliance) rather than financial payment obligations. Performance LCs may be drawn if the borrower fails to perform under the underlying contract. Some credit agreements include performance LCs within the LC sublimit while others require them to be issued under a separate surety bond basket.
children.name: Performance LCs
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 7 (LC framework)

children.definition: Categories of letters of credit that may be issued under the LC sublimit: standby (financial guarantee), commercial (trade finance), and performance LCs. DLS Preferred Row 7: 'Available for standby letters of credit or, if acceptable to the Letter of Credit Issuer, trade letters of credit.' The issuing bank has discretion over which LC types it will issue, particularly for trade (commercial) LCs.
children.name: LC Types
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 7 (LC types: standby and trade)

children.definition: Permitted indebtedness basket for surety bonds — three-party instruments where a surety company guarantees the borrower's performance or payment obligations to a third-party obligee. Surety bonds are used in construction, government contracting, and regulated industries where bonding is required by statute or contract. The surety has recourse against the borrower if a claim is paid, creating a contingent indemnity obligation that constitutes indebtedness.
children.name: Surety Bonds
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 88 (incurrence of guarantee or contingent obligations)

children.definition: Time drafts drawn on and accepted by a commercial bank, creating a negotiable instrument that the bank is unconditionally obligated to pay at maturity. Bankers' acceptances are used primarily in international trade finance to provide credit enhancement for import/export transactions. The bank's acceptance creates a guaranteed payment, and the borrower's obligation to reimburse the bank at maturity constitutes indebtedness under the credit agreement.
children.name: Banker's Acceptances

children.definition: Third-party instruments guaranteeing completion of contractual obligations in construction, government contracting, and similar industries where performance bonding is required. Performance bonds differ from surety bonds in that they specifically guarantee project completion rather than financial obligations. The borrower's indemnity obligation to the bond issuer if the bond is called constitutes indebtedness.
children.name: Performance Bonds

children.definition: Permitted indebtedness basket for surety bonds, performance bonds, bankers' acceptances, and similar non-letter-of-credit credit support instruments that create contingent obligations for the borrower. These instruments are typically issued in the ordinary course of business and are not subject to the LC sublimit, instead having a separate dedicated basket or falling within the general debt basket.
children.name: Surety Bonds / Banker's Acceptances
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 (alternative: other debt baskets)

children.definition: Whether letters of credit may include automatic renewal (evergreen) provisions that extend the LC for additional periods unless the issuing bank provides advance notice of non-renewal. DLS Preferred Row 7: LCs may 'provide, at the Borrower's option, for renewal thereof for additional periods of up to 12 months (which in no event shall extend beyond the date referred to in clause (b) above).' Auto-renewal LCs must still expire no later than 5 business days before the revolving facility maturity.

market_benchmarks.market_standard_value: 12-month initial term with auto-renewal up to maturity

children.name: Auto-Renewal Provisions
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 7 (LC auto-renewal provisions)

children.definition: Requirement that any letters of credit remaining outstanding at or near the revolving facility maturity date must be fully cash collateralized, since the revolving commitment that provides the credit support for the LCs is terminating. DLS Preferred Row 7: LCs must expire no later than 5 business days before final revolver maturity, with cash collateralization required for any LCs that cannot be terminated.
children.name: At Revolver Maturity
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 7 (LC expiration and maturity)

children.definition: Requirement that outstanding letters of credit be cash collateralized upon the occurrence of an event of default and acceleration, converting the contingent LC exposure into cash collateral that the administrative agent controls. Default-triggered cash collateralization ensures that the issuing bank's fronting exposure is protected when the borrower's creditworthiness has deteriorated.
children.name: Upon Default
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 7 (LC framework)

children.definition: The required cash deposit expressed as a percentage of the aggregate face amount of outstanding letters of credit, typically 103-105% to provide a buffer for fees, interest, and potential currency fluctuations. The margin above 100% ensures that the cash collateral is sufficient to cover all amounts that may become due under the LCs, including the issuing bank's fees and any interest on unreimbursed drawings.
children.name: Collateralization Percentage

children.definition: Events and conditions that trigger the requirement to cash collateralize outstanding letters of credit by depositing cash equal to the LC face amount (plus a margin, typically 103-105%) in a collateral account pledged to the administrative agent. Cash collateralization converts contingent LC exposure into funded credit-protected exposure. DLS Preferred Row 7: LCs expire no later than 5 business days before revolver maturity, requiring cash collateralization of any outstanding LCs at that point.
children.name: Cash Collateralization Triggers
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 7 (LC expiration relative to maturity)

children.definition: Letters of credit and surety bonds/banker's acceptances. DLS Preferred Row 7: letters of credit are a sublimit under the revolving facility, with 'the face amount of any outstanding letter of credit reducing availability under the Revolving Facility on a dollar-for-dollar basis.' DLS Row 13: Total Indebtedness includes 'all unreimbursed amounts under a letter of credit, banker's acceptance or similar instrument.' Distinguished from general debt baskets by being drawn against the revolving facility commitment rather than creating new funded debt.

concept_specific_notes: [neg_cov_debt.letters_of_credit] Universal basket (9/9). L/C obligations are typically a separate basket within the Indebtedness section. Sometimes lumped with 'obligations under this Agreement' basket rather than standalone.
search_strategy.fallback_escalation: Search for 'shall not incur' or 'Permitted Indebtedness' or 'incurrence of Indebtedness'. If none found, search for 'other Indebtedness' or 'aggregate principal amount' near negative covenant headings.

Cross-references to ratio test / Leverage Ratio definition
Cross-references to Permitted Acquisition / Limited Condition Acquisition
Section 2.14/2.20 for Incremental Facility mechanics (incremental_facility basket lives there, not in neg cov section)

cmm.notes: May include separate operational LC basket
May include separate operational LC basket

children.name: Letters of Credit / Surety Bonds
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 7 (LC mechanics), Row 13 (Total Indebtedness definition)

children.definition: Equity interest that the issuer is required to redeem mandatorily at a specified date, or that the holder has the right to require the issuer to repurchase, in either case within 91 days of the latest maturity date of the credit facility. Mandatory redemption creates a fixed payment obligation that is functionally identical to a debt maturity, which is why such equity is disqualified from treatment as true equity and instead classified as indebtedness.
children.name: Mandatory Redemption

red_flags.market_context: Preferred stock at non-guarantor subs is effectively hidden debt
red_flags.text: Uncapped issuance of preferred stock at non-guarantor restricted subsidiary — structurally senior to lenders and excluded from debt/covenant calculations

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (indebtedness definition)

children.definition: The 91-day lookback period before the latest maturity date of the credit facility that serves as the disqualification threshold: equity interests redeemable or puttable within this window are classified as disqualified stock. The 91-day buffer ensures that quasi-debt equity obligations cannot come due within three months of the credit facility's final maturity, preventing competition between equity redemption demands and senior debt repayment in the final months of the facility.
children.name: Maturity Window

red_flags.market_context: Preferred stock at non-guarantor subs is effectively hidden debt
red_flags.text: Uncapped issuance of preferred stock at non-guarantor restricted subsidiary — structurally senior to lenders and excluded from debt/covenant calculations

children.definition_source: Review Template Row 33 (Incremental – inside maturity basket); Review Template Row 37 (Refinancing Facilities – Inside Maturity)

children.definition: Equity interests that are convertible into or exchangeable for indebtedness at the option of the holder or issuer, which are classified as disqualified stock because the conversion feature means the instrument may become debt at any time. The conversion right creates a contingent increase in the borrower's debt level that would not be captured by the indebtedness covenant's basket analysis unless the convertible equity is preemptively classified as indebtedness.
children.name: Convertible to Debt

red_flags.market_context: Preferred stock at non-guarantor subs is effectively hidden debt
red_flags.text: Uncapped issuance of preferred stock at non-guarantor restricted subsidiary — structurally senior to lenders and excluded from debt/covenant calculations

children.definition_source: Review Template Row 72 (Negative Covenants - Indebtedness); Review Template Row 73 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Ratio Debt – amount); Review Template Row 74 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Ratio Debt – non-guarantor cap); Review Template Row 75 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Ratio Debt – terms); Review Template Row 76 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Contribution Debt); Review Template Row 77 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Incurred Acquisition Debt – amount); Review Template Row 78 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Incurred Acquisition Debt – non-guarantor cap); Review Template Row 79 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Assumed Acquisition Debt); Review Template Row 80 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Securitization Facilities); Review Template Row 81 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Sale-Leaseback debt); Review Template Row 82 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – General Basket); Review Template Row 83 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Non-guarantor/foreign subsidiary debt); Review Template Row 111 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments); Review Template Row 112 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – Scope); Review Template Row 113 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – Threshold); Review Template Row 114 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – General Basket); Review Template Row 115 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – Ratio Basket); Review Template Row 116 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – Refinancings); Review Template Row 117 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – Earnouts)

children.definition: The criteria that classify equity interests as disqualified stock (quasi-debt equity) within the indebtedness covenant: mandatory redemption rights, holder put rights exercisable within 91 days of the latest facility maturity, or convertibility into debt. Disqualified stock is treated as indebtedness because it creates fixed payment obligations resembling debt service. DLS Preferred Row 13: Total Indebtedness components include obligations that function as debt. KCT Cat 2 Item 3: 'Permit uncapped issuance of preferred stock at a non-guarantor restricted subsidiary that would be structurally senior to lenders.'
children.name: Definition

red_flags.market_context: Preferred stock at non-guarantor subs is effectively hidden debt
red_flags.text: Uncapped issuance of preferred stock at non-guarantor restricted subsidiary — structurally senior to lenders and excluded from debt/covenant calculations

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Total Indebtedness components); KCT Cat 2 Item 3 (uncapped preferred stock risk)

children.definition: Equity repurchase rights that are exercisable only upon a change of control event, which do not trigger disqualification because the change of control itself typically constitutes an event of default or mandatory prepayment event under the credit facility, making the equity repurchase obligation redundant with the broader consequences of the CoC trigger.
children.name: Change of Control Puts

red_flags.market_context: Preferred stock at non-guarantor subs is effectively hidden debt
red_flags.text: Uncapped issuance of preferred stock at non-guarantor restricted subsidiary — structurally senior to lenders and excluded from debt/covenant calculations

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 90 (CoC as EoD)

children.definition: Equity repurchase rights that are exercisable only upon a material asset disposition, which do not trigger disqualification because asset sale proceeds are typically subject to mandatory prepayment under the credit facility and the asset sale itself is governed by the disposition covenant. The equity put right is subordinate to the mandatory prepayment obligation.
children.name: Asset Sale Puts

red_flags.market_context: Preferred stock at non-guarantor subs is effectively hidden debt
red_flags.text: Uncapped issuance of preferred stock at non-guarantor restricted subsidiary — structurally senior to lenders and excluded from debt/covenant calculations

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (asset sale sweep)

children.definition: Equity repurchase obligations arising upon the termination of employment of officers, directors, or employees participating in management equity incentive programs, which do not trigger disqualification because these obligations are incidental to the equity incentive program rather than a scheduled redemption feature. Employee stock repurchases are typically subject to separate dollar caps under the restricted payments covenant.
children.name: Employee Stock Arrangements

red_flags.market_context: Preferred stock at non-guarantor subs is effectively hidden debt
red_flags.text: Uncapped issuance of preferred stock at non-guarantor restricted subsidiary — structurally senior to lenders and excluded from debt/covenant calculations

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 84 (RP: management buyback)

children.definition: Specified events or features of equity interests that do not trigger disqualification despite creating repurchase or redemption rights, because these events are not within the issuer's or holder's normal control. Standard carveouts include change of control puts, asset sale puts, and employee stock repurchase obligations that arise only upon extraordinary events rather than as scheduled payment obligations.
children.name: Market-Standard Carveouts

red_flags.market_context: Preferred stock at non-guarantor subs is effectively hidden debt
red_flags.text: Uncapped issuance of preferred stock at non-guarantor restricted subsidiary — structurally senior to lenders and excluded from debt/covenant calculations

children.definition: Fixed dollar ceiling on the aggregate liquidation preference or redemption price of disqualified stock outstanding at any time, providing a maximum exposure limit. The dollar cap is typically sized as a component of the general debt basket or as a standalone sub-limit within the indebtedness covenant.
children.name: Dollar Cap

red_flags.market_context: Preferred stock at non-guarantor subs is effectively hidden debt
red_flags.text: Uncapped issuance of preferred stock at non-guarantor restricted subsidiary — structurally senior to lenders and excluded from debt/covenant calculations

children.definition_source: Review Template Row 74 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Ratio Debt – non-guarantor cap); Review Template Row 78 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Incurred Acquisition Debt – non-guarantor cap)

children.definition: Disqualified stock capacity expressed as a percentage of LTM EBITDA, providing a grower mechanism that scales with borrower size. EBITDA-based caps for disqualified stock are less common than for other indebtedness baskets because disqualified stock issuance is typically an event-driven capital structure decision rather than an ongoing operational need.
children.name: EBITDA Percentage

red_flags.market_context: Preferred stock at non-guarantor subs is effectively hidden debt
red_flags.text: Uncapped issuance of preferred stock at non-guarantor restricted subsidiary — structurally senior to lenders and excluded from debt/covenant calculations

children.definition: Disqualified stock capacity expressed as the greater of a fixed dollar amount and a percentage of LTM EBITDA, providing a floor and grower mechanism. This structure is consistent with the general grower framework used across indebtedness baskets but is relatively uncommon for disqualified stock given the event-driven nature of preferred equity issuance.
children.name: Greater-Of

red_flags.market_context: Preferred stock at non-guarantor subs is effectively hidden debt
red_flags.text: Uncapped issuance of preferred stock at non-guarantor restricted subsidiary — structurally senior to lenders and excluded from debt/covenant calculations

children.definition_source: general grower structure from DLS Preferred Row 79

children.definition: How the aggregate amount of disqualified stock that may be outstanding is limited within the indebtedness covenant, expressed as a fixed dollar amount, EBITDA percentage, or greater-of grower structure. Because disqualified stock is treated as indebtedness, it consumes capacity under the applicable debt basket. KCT Cat 2 Item 3: flag 'uncapped issuance of preferred stock at a non-guarantor restricted subsidiary that would be structurally senior to lenders or excluded from debt incurrence or covenant calculations.'
children.name: Cap Structure

red_flags.market_context: Preferred stock at non-guarantor subs is effectively hidden debt
red_flags.text: Uncapped issuance of preferred stock at non-guarantor restricted subsidiary — structurally senior to lenders and excluded from debt/covenant calculations

children.definition_source: KCT Cat 2 Item 3 (uncapped preferred stock at non-guarantor as risk)

children.definition: Whether disqualified stock is counted as indebtedness for purposes of the Section 6.01 negative covenant, consuming capacity under the applicable indebtedness basket when issued. When included, the borrower must identify a basket (general debt, ratio debt, or a dedicated disqualified stock basket) with sufficient capacity before issuing disqualified equity.
children.name: Included in Indebtedness

red_flags.market_context: Preferred stock at non-guarantor subs is effectively hidden debt
red_flags.text: Uncapped issuance of preferred stock at non-guarantor restricted subsidiary — structurally senior to lenders and excluded from debt/covenant calculations

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 (indebtedness covenant)

children.definition: Whether the liquidation preference or redemption price of disqualified stock is included in the numerator of the leverage ratio calculation (Total Indebtedness), increasing the reported leverage and reducing available ratio-based capacity. When included, disqualified stock directly affects the borrower's ability to incur additional debt under ratio baskets, incremental facilities, and other ratio-tested provisions.

market_benchmarks.pc_guidance: Include where appropriate per PC line 150

ratio_debt_ied_cmm.value: Permitted with full protections — MFN, non-guarantor cap, maturity/WAL

ratio_debt_ied_lmm.value: No IED (bank preferred); if permitted, full MFN/maturity/WAL protections

children.name: Included in Leverage Ratios

Limited to debt for borrowed money capital lease obligations/purchase money debt and obligations evidenced by bonds, debentures notes and similar instruments
No cap on cash netting
No requirement to keep the unrestricted cash in deposit account subject to a control agreement [...]
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Spectrum from fixed-dollar cap (lender) to ratio-based (borrower). Market often lands on greater-of formulation.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Disqualified stock included in Total Indebtedness for leverage calculations; no exclusion for preferred equity instruments

red_flags.market_context: Template: consider treatment of concurrent revolver draws in incurrence tests
red_flags.text: Leverage ratios only count 'debt for borrowed money' — excludes concurrent revolver draws and other liabilities

red_flags.market_context: Preferred stock at non-guarantor subs is effectively hidden debt
red_flags.text: Uncapped issuance of preferred stock at non-guarantor restricted subsidiary — structurally senior to lenders and excluded from debt/covenant calculations

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Total Indebtedness for leverage calculation)

children.definition: How disqualified stock is treated in the credit agreement's financial calculations — specifically whether it is included in the definition of Total Indebtedness for leverage ratio calculations, whether it is counted toward incurrence tests, and whether dividends on disqualified stock are treated as interest expense for coverage ratio purposes. DLS Preferred Row 13: Total Indebtedness includes disqualified stock by implication through the 'obligations evidenced by bonds, debentures, notes and similar instruments' component.
children.name: Covenant Treatment

red_flags.market_context: Preferred stock at non-guarantor subs is effectively hidden debt
red_flags.text: Uncapped issuance of preferred stock at non-guarantor restricted subsidiary — structurally senior to lenders and excluded from debt/covenant calculations

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Total Indebtedness components)

children.definition: Whether disqualified stock includes features allowing conversion into common equity (which would reclassify it out of indebtedness) or into debt instruments (which would change its treatment within the indebtedness framework). Conversion from disqualified stock to qualified equity reduces leverage; conversion to debt may require sufficient basket capacity for the resulting debt obligation.
children.name: Conversion Features

red_flags.market_context: Preferred stock at non-guarantor subs is effectively hidden debt
red_flags.text: Uncapped issuance of preferred stock at non-guarantor restricted subsidiary — structurally senior to lenders and excluded from debt/covenant calculations

children.definition: Equity interests that must be redeemed, are redeemable at the option of the holder, or are convertible into debt before the credit facility maturity date — treated as indebtedness for covenant purposes. DLS Preferred Row 13: leverage ratios include 'guarantees of the foregoing' in Total Indebtedness. KCT Cat 2 Item 3: 'Permit uncapped issuance of preferred stock at a non-guarantor restricted subsidiary that would be structurally senior to lenders or excluded from debt incurrence or covenant calculations.' Distinguished from equity contributions (which build capacity) by being classified as debt due to mandatory redemption features.

National Vision uses 'Disqualified Stock or preferred stock' formulation. Removed 'Disqualified Capital Stock' (0/9 in debt sections — only in definitions). Absent in Arch, Sleep Number, Red Rock.

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Employee Stock Repurchases
Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Unrestricted Subsidiary Stock

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Total Indebtedness definition); KCT Cat 2 Item 3

children.definition: Permitted indebtedness basket expressly carving out the initial term loan facility from the general prohibition on incurring debt. This is the first basket in every credit agreement's indebtedness covenant, referencing the funded term loan commitments on the closing date (including any increase funded to cover flex OID/upfront fees). DLS Preferred Row 8: 'At least $[  ]; Amortization: 0.25% per quarter, bullet at maturity.' DLS Preferred Row 79: indebtedness covenant first item is 'indebtedness under the Credit Facilities (including any incremental, delayed draw and refinancing facilities permitted thereunder).'
children.name: Term Loan

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Amount increased to fund “flex” OID/Upfront fees [only applicable for deals where has pricing flex]
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market landing between lender-preferred and borrower-aggressive positions; specific terms deal-dependent.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position:
At least $[         ]
Amortization: 0.25% per quarter, bullet at maturity.

Maturity: [   ] years.

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 8 (Term Loan structure); DLS Preferred Row 79 (indebtedness covenant basket (i))

children.definition: Permitted indebtedness basket for the revolving credit facility commitment as initially established on the closing date, including letter of credit sublimits and swingline subfacilities. The revolver is carved out under the same Section 6.01 basket that covers all credit facility debt. DLS Preferred Row 6: revolver availability includes amounts to fund transaction costs, working capital needs, and replacement of existing letters of credit. Revolver usage affects leverage calculations and may trigger springing financial covenants.
children.name: Revolving Facility
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 6 (Revolver structure and availability); DLS Preferred Row 79 (indebtedness covenant basket (i))

children.definition: Permitted indebtedness basket for delayed draw term loan commitments established on the closing date but drawn in one or more fundings after closing, typically to finance permitted acquisitions. DLS Preferred Row 14: DDTL conditions include pro forma compliance with financial covenants, leverage ratios, and equity contribution requirements for the funded acquisition. PC Term Comparison: 'Typically limited to Permitted Acquisitions; typically at 18 month commitment; occasionally 24 months.' KCT Cat 2 Item 2: DDTL commitments should be tested at incurrence and all DDTLs accounted for in forward ratio tests.
children.name: Delayed Draw Term Loan
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (DDTL conditions); PC Term Comparison lines 173-186 (DDTL terms); KCT Cat 2 Item 2 (DDTL testing)

children.definition: The original committed amounts under the term loan and revolving facility as of the closing date. DLS Preferred Row 8: 'At least $[X]. Amortization: 0.25% per quarter, bullet at maturity. Maturity: [X] years.' Row 6: revolving facility with stated commitment. These amounts define the starting point for all capacity calculations and pro rata share allocations. Distinguished from incremental commitments (which are post-closing additions) by being the founding facility commitment.
children.name: Initial Commitments
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Rows 6-8

children.definition: Cross-reference to the incremental facility provisions (typically Article 2, Section 2.20 or similar) that permits additional commitments under the credit agreement. DLS Preferred Row 79: '(including any incremental, delayed draw and refinancing facilities permitted thereunder).' Distinguished from standalone incremental capacity by being the indebtedness covenant permission that authorizes incremental facilities.
children.name: Incremental Facilities (Cross-Reference)

red_flags.market_context: Inside maturity should be limited to a small carveout for bridges and escrowed amounts
red_flags.text: Incremental debt can mature before maturity date of existing facilities — creates effective seniority

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 item (i)

children.definition: Cross-reference within the credit facility debt basket to permitted refinancing provisions that allow existing credit facility tranches to be refinanced with replacement debt under the same credit agreement. DLS Preferred Row 79: basket (i) includes 'any incremental, delayed draw and refinancing facilities permitted thereunder.' This ensures that permitted refinancings of the initial term loans do not require separate basket capacity, as they replace rather than add to existing credit facility obligations.
children.name: Refinancing of Credit Facility Debt (Cross-Reference)
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 (credit facility debt basket including refinancing facilities); DLS Preferred Row 16 (Refinancing Debt conditions)

children.definition: Overall cap on aggregate commitments under the credit facilities, inclusive of all initial, incremental, delayed draw, and refinancing facilities. May be explicitly stated or implied by the combination of individual basket limits. Distinguished from individual facility caps by governing the total credit facility footprint.
children.name: Aggregate Cap
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79

children.definition: Indebtedness under the credit facilities themselves, including initial term loans, revolving facility, and any incremental, delayed draw, and refinancing facilities permitted thereunder. DLS Preferred Row 79: '(i) indebtedness under the Credit Facilities [(including any incremental, delayed draw and refinancing facilities permitted thereunder)].' This is the first and universal basket in every credit agreement — it permits the debt being documented. Distinguished from all other baskets by authorizing the primary facility itself rather than additional post-closing debt.

concept_specific_notes: [neg_cov_debt.incremental_facility] Incremental facility mechanics (7/9, absent in Sleep Number and Arch). IMPORTANT: The substantive incremental provisions live in Article II (loan mechanics), NOT in the Indebtedness covenant section. The neg cov section typically just has a cross-reference basket (e.g., 'Indebtedness under Section 2.14'). Search must follow the xref to Article II to find the actual terms. Added 'Maximum Incremental Facilities Amount' and 'Incremental Cap' for National Vision's variant phrasing.
[neg_cov_debt.incremental_facility] xref_scope: Section 2.14 or 2.20 (not in the Indebtedness section itself)

bsl.typical_structure: Multi-tranche TL + Revolver + incremental + refinancing facilities
Multi-tranche TL + Revolver + incremental + refinancing facilities

children.name: Credit Facility Debt

red_flags.pattern: Catch-all permits debt beyond initial commitments
red_flags.rationale: Scope ambiguity in what 'credit facility debt' covers

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 item (i)

children.definition: Fixed dollar ceiling on the aggregate outstanding amount of loans and advances to directors, officers, and employees. The dollar cap ensures that the total insider lending exposure remains immaterial relative to the credit facility, preventing management advances from becoming a material use of the restricted group's cash resources. Typical sizing ranges from $1M-$5M in LMM/CMM transactions to $5M-$10M in UMM deals.
children.name: Dollar Cap

children.definition: Management advance cap expressed as a percentage of LTM EBITDA rather than a fixed dollar amount, providing a grower mechanism that scales with borrower size. EBITDA-based caps for management advances are relatively rare because the purpose of the basket (employee loans) does not naturally scale with business performance. When present, the percentage is typically small (1-2% of EBITDA).
children.name: EBITDA Percentage

children.definition: Aggregate ceiling on outstanding management loans and advances, expressed as a fixed dollar amount ($1M-$10M typical range) or EBITDA percentage. The cap limits the borrower's exposure to non-arm's-length lending to insiders. Management advance caps are relatively small compared to other indebtedness baskets because these obligations represent a potential leakage path for restricted payments disguised as loans.
children.name: Cap Structure
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 88 (other neg covs)

children.definition: Corporate officers (CEO, CFO, COO, and other C-suite or named executive officers) who are eligible to receive loans and advances under the management advances basket. Officer eligibility is standard and non-controversial because officers have fiduciary duties to the borrower and their loans are typically for business-related purposes such as relocation expenses and equity purchases.
children.name: Officers

children.definition: Current employees of the borrower and its restricted subsidiaries who are eligible to receive loans and advances under the management advances basket. Employee eligibility broadens the beneficiary pool beyond officers and directors. Loans to rank-and-file employees are typically for relocation, travel advances, and similar business-related purposes. The aggregate cap limits total exposure regardless of the number of individual employee loans.
children.name: Employees

children.definition: Members of the board of directors of the borrower or any restricted subsidiary who are eligible to receive loans and advances under the management advances basket. Director loans are less common than officer/employee loans because independent directors typically have limited operational involvement. Loans to directors may include advances for director fees, liability insurance, and indemnification obligations.
children.name: Directors

children.definition: Former directors, officers, and employees who remain eligible to receive or maintain outstanding loans and advances under the management advances basket after their departure from the borrower's employ. This extension is typically limited to maintaining loans outstanding at the time of termination rather than making new advances. Some credit agreements restrict post-termination eligibility to a specified wind-down period (90-180 days).
children.name: Former Employees

children.definition: Categories of individuals eligible to receive loans and advances from the borrower under the management advances basket: typically limited to current officers, directors, and employees of the borrower and its restricted subsidiaries. The eligible person definition determines the potential beneficiary universe and should be narrow enough to prevent the basket from becoming an indirect restricted payment mechanism to sponsor-related individuals.
children.name: Eligible Persons

children.definition: Advances for moving, relocation, and housing expenses incurred by officers and employees in connection with job transfers, reassignments, or new hires. Relocation advances are among the most standard and non-controversial permitted purposes because they directly serve the borrower's business interest in attracting and retaining talent.
children.name: Relocation Assistance

children.definition: Advances for business-related travel expenses including transportation, lodging, meals, and incidental expenses incurred by officers and employees in the course of performing their duties. Business travel advances are standard in all transactions and typically represent short-term amounts that are reimbursed or offset against expense reports within 30-60 days.
children.name: Business Travel

children.definition: Loans to directors, officers, and employees to purchase equity interests in the borrower, holdings, or a parent entity as part of management equity incentive programs. These loans align management interests with equity holders by enabling share ownership, but represent a potential leakage path because if the loans are subsequently forgiven, they effectively function as cash compensation. The equity purchase purpose is more scrutinized in private credit where the sponsor controls the equity program.
children.name: Equity Purchase
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 84 (management buyback interaction)

children.definition: Unrestricted purpose for management advances, permitting loans to directors, officers, and employees for any purpose without requiring a business nexus. This is the most aggressive formulation because it allows the management advance basket to function as a personal lending facility, potentially enabling cash extraction from the restricted group for non-business purposes. Most credit agreements restrict management advances to specified business-related purposes.
children.name: General Purpose
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 104 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – General Basket); Review Template Row 114 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – General Basket)

children.definition: Restrictions on the purposes for which management loans and advances may be used, limiting the basket to business-related or employee-benefit purposes rather than serving as a general lending facility to insiders. Purpose restrictions prevent the management advances basket from being used as a mechanism for extracting cash from the restricted group for the personal benefit of management.
children.name: Purpose Limitation

children.definition: Management advances payable on demand by the borrower, providing maximum flexibility to recall loans when cash is needed for operations or debt service. Demand basis is the most protective repayment structure for lenders because the borrower retains the right to accelerate repayment at any time without cause.
children.name: Demand Basis

children.definition: Management advances with a specified maturity date by which repayment must occur, providing certainty of repayment timing but limiting the borrower's ability to accelerate collection. Fixed-term management loans are more common for equity purchase loans where the repayment is coordinated with the management equity program's vesting schedule.
children.name: Fixed Term
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 14 (Term Sheet); Review Template Row 33 (Incremental – inside maturity basket); Review Template Row 37 (Refinancing Facilities – Inside Maturity); Review Template Row 127 (Other Term Sheet Issues – LCT, EoDs, Voting, Assignments, Pricing); Review Template Row 160 (Ticking Fee (Term/Revolver))

children.definition: Management advances that become immediately due and payable upon the termination of the recipient's employment with the borrower or any restricted subsidiary. The termination trigger ensures that management advances do not remain outstanding after the employee's relationship with the borrower ends, preventing loans from converting into uncollectible receivables from former employees.
children.name: Repayment on Termination

children.definition: Terms governing how and when management loans and advances must be repaid, including whether repayment is on demand, at a fixed maturity, or triggered by employment termination. Repayment provisions ensure that management advances remain temporary and do not accumulate as permanent obligations, which would resemble restricted payments rather than loans.
children.name: Repayment Terms

children.definition: Loans or advances to directors, officers, employees, and management. Typically subject to a fixed dollar cap and limited to specified purposes (relocation, business expenses, equity purchases). Part of the indebtedness covenant's operational baskets. Distinguished from intercompany debt (which flows between corporate entities) by flowing to individuals rather than subsidiaries.

concept_specific_notes: [neg_cov_debt.employee_obligations] Present in 6/9 deals. Permits indebtedness to employees/officers/directors (usually for deferred compensation, stock repurchases, or relocation). Often has a dollar cap.
