Cross-references to Permitted Acquisition / Limited Condition Acquisition
Section 2.14/2.20 for Incremental Facility mechanics (incremental_facility basket lives there, not in neg cov section)

children.name: Management Advances

red_flags.rationale: Disproportionate management loans relative to business
Management loans for any purpose — potential leakage
Extended liability without ongoing employment relationship

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 84 (RP: 'customary exceptions for distributions necessary to pay Sponsor advisory' fees)

children.definition: Obligations arising from bilateral and multilateral set-off arrangements that reduce gross intercompany payment flows to net amounts, minimizing cross-border transaction costs and foreign exchange exposure. Netting services create contingent obligations because the netting provider (typically a bank) guarantees settlement of net amounts, and the difference between gross and net flows represents an intraday or overnight credit exposure to the borrower.
children.name: Netting Arrangements

children.definition: Permitted indebtedness arising from centralized cash management arrangements where subsidiary account balances are swept into a master account or notionally pooled for interest optimization. Cash pooling creates intercompany debt obligations between the master account holder and contributing subsidiaries, as balances are technically lent between entities. These arrangements are standard for multinational corporate groups and are generally uncapped when provided by a lender.
children.name: Cash Pooling

children.definition: Obligations arising from automated clearing house (ACH) processing, wire transfer services, payroll processing, and similar payment services that create intraday or overnight credit exposures between the borrower and its banking service providers. Treasury management services are essential for day-to-day operations and are universally permitted, typically without a cap when the service provider is a lender or lender affiliate.
children.name: Treasury Management Services

children.definition: Obligations arising from corporate credit cards, debit facilities, purchasing cards, and similar banking products used in the ordinary course of business. Bank product obligations create unsecured credit exposure that is technically indebtedness but is necessary for routine commercial operations. These obligations are typically permitted without a cap when the bank product provider is a lender or lender affiliate.
children.name: Bank Product Obligations

children.definition: Depository services including deposit account maintenance, lockbox collection arrangements, and controlled disbursement services that create minor contingent obligations between the borrower and its depository banks. These services are integral to the DACA (deposit account control agreement) framework that gives the administrative agent control over borrower bank accounts.
children.name: Depository Services
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 67 (security: deposit and securities account control agreements)

children.definition: Categories of treasury and banking activities whose resulting obligations are permitted under the cash management basket within the indebtedness covenant: netting services, cash pooling, treasury management, bank products, and depository services. These obligations arise from ordinary-course banking relationships rather than borrowing, but create contingent liabilities that must be addressed under the indebtedness covenant.
children.name: Scope / Services
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 88 (other neg covs)

children.definition: Requirement that cash management service providers be current lenders under the credit facility or affiliates of current lenders. This restriction ensures that cash management obligations are secured pari passu with the credit facility when the provider is within the syndicate, and creates operational alignment between banking services and lending relationships.
children.name: Must Be Lender or Affiliate

children.definition: Qualification providing that the cash management service provider only needs to be a lender or lender affiliate at the time the arrangement is established, rather than maintaining lender status throughout the life of the cash management relationship. This practical accommodation prevents disruption to banking operations if the service provider subsequently sells its loans.
children.name: Lender at Time of Entry

children.definition: Whether the borrower may use cash management service providers that are not lenders or lender affiliates, expanding the universe of potential banking partners. Non-lender cash management providers are more common in multinational operations where local banking relationships in foreign jurisdictions may not overlap with the lending syndicate. When non-lender providers are permitted, their obligations are typically subject to a dollar cap and remain unsecured.
children.name: Non-Lender Permitted
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 74 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Ratio Debt – non-guarantor cap); Review Template Row 78 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Incurred Acquisition Debt – non-guarantor cap); Review Template Row 83 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Non-guarantor/foreign subsidiary debt)

children.definition: Whether the provider of cash management services must be a lender under the credit facility or an affiliate of a lender, mirroring the counterparty restrictions applied to hedging obligations. The lender-required counterparty restriction ensures that cash management obligations are provided by institutions within the lending syndicate and subject to the intercreditor arrangements governing shared collateral and payment waterfall.
children.name: Counterparty Restrictions
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 67 (account control agreements)

children.definition: Cash management obligations are uncapped when the service provider is a lender under the credit facility or an affiliate of a lender, reflecting the view that intra-syndicate cash management obligations are secured pari passu and create no incremental risk to the lender group because they are effectively lending to themselves as a group.
children.name: Uncapped with Lender

children.definition: Fixed dollar ceiling on cash management obligations owed to non-lender service providers, limiting the borrower's unsecured exposure to third-party banking partners. The dollar cap is typically sized at a level that accommodates ordinary-course banking relationships without creating material unsecured obligations that could compete with the credit facility in enforcement.
children.name: Dollar Cap (Non-Lender)
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 74 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Ratio Debt – non-guarantor cap); Review Template Row 78 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Incurred Acquisition Debt – non-guarantor cap)

children.definition: Whether and how the aggregate amount of cash management obligations is capped within the indebtedness covenant. The cap treatment typically differs by counterparty type: obligations with lender counterparties are often uncapped (because they share collateral and participate in the waterfall), while obligations with non-lender counterparties are subject to a fixed dollar cap to limit unsecured exposure.
children.name: Cap Structure
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 74 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Ratio Debt – non-guarantor cap); Review Template Row 78 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Incurred Acquisition Debt – non-guarantor cap)

children.definition: Cash management obligations owed to lender or lender-affiliate service providers that share in the collateral package on a pari passu basis with the credit facility obligations. Secured treatment aligns the cash management provider's recovery interest with their lending interest, ensuring consistent enforcement incentives.
children.name: Secured (Lender Counterparty)
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 67 (all assets security)

children.definition: Requirement that cash management obligations owed to non-lender service providers remain unsecured, preventing third-party banks from obtaining liens on the collateral that would dilute first-lien recovery for credit facility lenders.
children.name: Unsecured (Non-Lender)

children.definition: Whether cash management obligations are secured by the same collateral package as the credit facility and rank pari passu in the payment waterfall. Like hedging obligations, the security treatment of cash management obligations depends on the counterparty: lender-affiliated providers share in collateral, while non-lender providers are typically unsecured.
children.name: Security
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 67 (security: all assets)

children.definition: Permitted cash management obligations, covering treasury and banking services including netting services, overdraft facilities, employee credit card programs, and automated clearing house arrangements. Typically permitted when provided by the administrative agent, lenders, or their affiliates. Distinguished from hedging obligations (which govern derivative instruments) by covering operational banking services.

concept_specific_notes: [neg_cov_debt.cash_management] Present in 6/9 deals. Permits indebtedness under cash management/treasury services agreements. Defined term 'Cash Management Agreement' is in Section 1.01. Absent in simpler IG-style deals.
search_strategy.fallback_escalation: Search for 'shall not incur' or 'Permitted Indebtedness' or 'incurrence of Indebtedness'. If none found, search for 'other Indebtedness' or 'aggregate principal amount' near negative covenant headings.
xref_follow: Section 1.01 for Indebtedness/Debt definition
Cross-references to ratio test / Leverage Ratio definition
Cross-references to Permitted Acquisition / Limited Condition Acquisition
Section 2.14/2.20 for Incremental Facility mechanics (incremental_facility basket lives there, not in neg cov section)

bsl.typical: Uncapped with lenders, larger non-lender caps

lmm.typical: Small fixed cap ($2-5M) or uncapped with lenders

bsl.typical: Uncapped with lenders, larger non-lender caps

lmm.typical: Small fixed cap ($2-5M) or uncapped with lenders

children.name: Cash Management Obligations

red_flags.rationale: Obligations to parties outside syndicate without limit

red_flags.pattern: Cash management obligations secured by collateral — non-lender

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 67 (hedges/cash management secured status)

children.definition: Dollar or EBITDA percentage cap on customer deposit obligations, limiting the aggregate amount of unearned customer advances outstanding at any time. The cap prevents the borrower from using customer deposits as an alternative financing source by collecting large advance payments without delivering corresponding goods or services. The cap is typically sized to accommodate ordinary-course deposit volumes.
children.name: Cap
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 74 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Ratio Debt – non-guarantor cap); Review Template Row 78 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Incurred Acquisition Debt – non-guarantor cap)

children.definition: Requirement that customer deposit obligations must arise in the ordinary course of the borrower's commercial operations, preventing the borrower from soliciting advance payments or deposits outside its normal business practices solely to generate cash (which would resemble a funding transaction rather than a commercial arrangement).
children.name: Ordinary Course Requirement

children.definition: Permitted indebtedness basket for deposits, advances, and prepayments received from customers in the ordinary course of the borrower's commercial operations. Customer deposits create liabilities because the borrower owes a product or service (or refund) in return, and these obligations technically constitute indebtedness. The basket ensures that routine commercial practices are not inadvertently blocked by the indebtedness covenant.
children.name: Customer Deposits / Advance Payments
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 104 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – General Basket); Review Template Row 105 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Ratio Basket); Review Template Row 108 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Post-IPO Basket); Review Template Row 110 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Permitted Tax Distribution); Review Template Row 111 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments); Review Template Row 112 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – Scope); Review Template Row 113 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – Threshold); Review Template Row 114 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – General Basket); Review Template Row 115 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – Ratio Basket); Review Template Row 116 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – Refinancings); Review Template Row 117 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – Earnouts)

children.definition: Fixed dollar ceiling on the aggregate amount of insurance premium financing obligations outstanding at any time. The cap is typically sized to accommodate the borrower's annual insurance premium budget, which is a relatively predictable and immaterial amount relative to total indebtedness.
children.name: Cap
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 74 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Ratio Debt – non-guarantor cap); Review Template Row 78 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Incurred Acquisition Debt – non-guarantor cap)

children.definition: Requirement that insurance premium financing debt must arise in the ordinary course of business, limiting the basket to commercially standard premium financing arrangements and preventing the borrower from using insurance premium financing as a general-purpose borrowing mechanism.
children.name: Ordinary Course

children.definition: Permitted indebtedness for financing the payment of insurance premiums over installments rather than in a lump sum, allowing the borrower to spread insurance costs across the policy period. Insurance premium financing is a standard commercial practice that creates a relatively low-risk obligation secured by the unearned premium (the insurance company's obligation to refund premiums if the policy is cancelled). The basket ensures that routine insurance arrangements are not restricted.
children.name: Insurance Premium Financing

children.definition: Whether the indebtedness covenant includes an express carveout for workers' compensation obligations. Most credit agreements permit workers' comp as part of a broader operational obligations basket rather than a standalone permission. The inclusion is non-controversial because these obligations are statutory and cannot be avoided.
children.name: Included in Basket
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 82 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – General Basket); Review Template Row 86 (Negative Covenants – Liens – General Basket); Review Template Row 87 (Negative Covenants – Liens – Ratio Basket); Review Template Row 92 (Negative Covenants – Investments – General Basket); Review Template Row 93 (Negative Covenants – Investments – Ratio Basket); Review Template Row 97 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions – 75% Cash Consideration Basket); Review Template Row 98 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions – General Basket); Review Template Row 104 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – General Basket); Review Template Row 105 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Ratio Basket); Review Template Row 108 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Post-IPO Basket); Review Template Row 114 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – General Basket); Review Template Row 115 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – Ratio Basket)

children.definition: Surety bonds posted by the borrower with state workers' compensation regulators or insurance carriers as security for self-insured workers' compensation obligations. Bonding creates a contingent indemnity obligation that constitutes indebtedness under broad definitions, which is why an express carveout is needed to prevent these statutory requirements from consuming basket capacity.
children.name: Bonding Requirements

children.definition: Permitted indebtedness basket for workers' compensation obligations, including self-insurance reserves, surety bonds posted to state regulators, and similar statutory requirements. Workers' compensation obligations are mandated by law and are not discretionary, making this basket a necessary carveout from the general indebtedness prohibition.
children.name: Workers Compensation Obligations
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 88 (other neg covs)

children.definition: Fixed dollar ceiling on the aggregate face amount of performance bonds, bid bonds, and similar instruments outstanding at any time. The cap is typically sized to accommodate the borrower's ordinary-course bonding needs, which vary significantly by industry.
children.name: Cap
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 74 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Ratio Debt – non-guarantor cap); Review Template Row 78 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Incurred Acquisition Debt – non-guarantor cap)

children.definition: Qualifying condition requiring that performance bonds and similar guarantee instruments be issued in connection with the borrower's ordinary course of business, preventing the borrower from using the performance bond basket for non-operational guarantee obligations that would more appropriately fall under the general debt or guarantee baskets.
children.name: Ordinary Course

children.definition: Permitted indebtedness basket for performance bonds, bid bonds, completion bonds, and similar instruments guaranteeing the borrower's contractual obligations to third parties. Performance bonds are common in construction, government contracting, and other industries where contract performance must be guaranteed by a third-party surety.
children.name: Performance Bonds / Bid Bonds

children.definition: Dollar or EBITDA percentage cap on equipment financing obligations, limiting the aggregate amount of specialized equipment financing beyond the capital lease/PM basket. The cap prevents equipment financing from becoming a significant additional debt source that circumvents the main capital lease capacity controls.
children.name: Cap
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 74 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Ratio Debt – non-guarantor cap); Review Template Row 78 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Incurred Acquisition Debt – non-guarantor cap)

children.definition: Requirement that equipment financing be limited to the specific assets being financed, with security interests attaching only to the equipment purchased. This asset-specific limitation prevents equipment financing from becoming a general secured lending facility and mirrors the asset-attachment requirement of the capital lease/PM basket.
children.name: Asset-Specific

children.definition: Separate sub-allocation within the equipment financing basket for vehicle fleet financing, covering auto leases, fleet management arrangements, and similar vehicle-specific financing. Vehicle financing may have a separate sub-basket because fleet vehicles are typically financed through manufacturer-affiliated finance companies with standardized terms that differ from general equipment financing.
children.name: Vehicle Financing

children.definition: Permitted indebtedness for the acquisition of specific equipment beyond the purchase money basket, covering specialized financing arrangements (vendor financing, fleet financing, technology equipment leases) that supplement the capital lease/PM basket. This separate basket may exist when the capital lease/PM basket is sized for general equipment needs, and the borrower requires additional capacity for specific equipment categories.
children.name: Equipment Financing

children.definition: Maximum dollar amount that an individual debt obligation (or aggregate obligations) may not exceed to qualify under the de minimis exception. The threshold is typically set low enough to be immaterial relative to the credit facility size but high enough to accommodate routine small-scale obligations without requiring formal basket compliance analysis.
children.name: Dollar Threshold
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 99 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions – De Minimis Threshold); Review Template Row 113 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – Threshold); Review Template Row 125 (Negative Covenants – Transactions with Affiliates – De Minimis Threshold)

children.definition: Whether the de minimis threshold applies on a per-obligation basis (each individual debt item must be below the threshold) or on an aggregate basis (total de minimis debt across all items must be below the threshold). Per-occurrence thresholds allow unlimited individual items as long as each is small, while aggregate thresholds cap total de minimis exposure regardless of the number of individual items.
children.name: Per Occurrence

children.definition: Small-amount exceptions permitting immaterial debt (typically under $1M per obligation or $5M in aggregate) that fall below negotiation thresholds and are not economically significant enough to warrant individual basket compliance analysis. De minimis baskets prevent administrative burden from the indebtedness covenant blocking trivially small obligations.
children.name: De Minimis Carveouts
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 99 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions – De Minimis Threshold); Review Template Row 125 (Negative Covenants – Transactions with Affiliates – De Minimis Threshold)

children.definition: Pre-existing debt obligations of the borrower and its subsidiaries that are listed on a schedule to the credit agreement as of the closing date and are expressly permitted to remain outstanding. Scheduled existing debt represents committed obligations that were part of the capital structure underwritten by the lenders and does not consume post-closing basket capacity.
children.name: Scheduled on Closing Date
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 (alternative: existing debt under Acquisition Agreement)

children.definition: Whether scheduled existing debt may be refinanced with replacement debt without consuming new basket capacity, subject to the same refinancing debt conditions (principal cap, maturity floor, WALM, seniority restrictions) that apply to credit facility refinancings. Refinancing rights for existing debt allow the borrower to restructure pre-existing obligations without needing to identify separate basket capacity for the replacement debt.
children.name: Refinancing Permitted
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 16 (refinancing conditions)

children.definition: Debt existing at the closing date that is permitted to remain outstanding, typically documented in a schedule to the credit agreement. DLS Preferred Row 79 alternative (vii): 'indebtedness permitted to be incurred and/or remain outstanding under the Acquisition Agreement.' This is the grandfather clause — pre-existing debt is permitted regardless of whether it would otherwise comply with the negative covenant baskets.
children.name: Existing Debt at Closing
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 alternative (vii)

children.definition: Requirement that guaranteed obligations must themselves be permitted under the indebtedness covenant, preventing the guarantee basket from being used to support obligations that would not independently pass basket analysis. This 'derivative permission' ensures that guarantee capacity is bounded by the underlying debt capacity.
children.name: Of Permitted Debt Only
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (guarantees of Total Indebtedness components)

children.definition: Dollar ceiling on the aggregate face amount of guarantees of third-party obligations, limiting the borrower group's contingent liability exposure. Guarantees of intra-group permitted debt are typically uncapped (because the underlying debt is already basket-tested), while guarantees of third-party obligations are capped to limit contingent exposure.
children.name: Cap
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 88 (incurrence of guarantee or contingent obligations)

children.definition: Permitted indebtedness basket for guarantees of obligations that are themselves permitted under the indebtedness covenant, ensuring that a subsidiary's guarantee of another entity's permitted debt does not require separate basket capacity. DLS Preferred Row 13: Total Indebtedness includes 'guarantees of the foregoing.' The guarantee basket applies to both upstream guarantees (subsidiary guaranteeing parent debt) and cross-guarantees (sibling entity guarantees).
children.name: Guarantee Obligations
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (guarantees in Total Indebtedness)

children.definition: Dollar or EBITDA percentage cap on subordinated debt within the other permitted debt baskets, limiting the amount of junior unsecured or payment-subordinated debt that may be outstanding. The subordinated debt basket provides a dedicated capacity for junior obligations that may not fit within other baskets (ratio debt, contribution debt, or Available Amount debt). PC Term Comparison line 528: second lien transactions involve 'cushions on dollar baskets only and not ratios.'
children.name: Cap
children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 528 (second lien basket cushions)

children.definition: The depth of subordination required for debt incurred under the subordinated debt basket: full payment subordination (all payments blocked during default), limited subordination (only principal payments blocked), or contractual subordination (subordinated in right of payment but not in lien priority). Deeper subordination provides greater protection to senior lenders but reduces the attractiveness of the subordinated debt to potential investors.
children.name: Subordination Depth
children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 529 ('Anti-layering: avoid 1.5 lien')

children.definition: Basket for subordinated indebtedness, typically from sponsors or affiliates. DLS Preferred Row 85: restricted debt prepayments 'Applies to junior lien, unsecured and subordinated indebtedness.' PC Term Comparison: seller debt in CMM/LMM 'may require subordination terms and other acceptable terms (not cash pay, no covs, later maturity; at Holdco).' Distinguished from ratio debt (which may be subordinated but is ratio-tested) by having specific subordination requirements without a leverage test.
children.name: Subordinated Debt Basket
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 85; PC Term Comparison line 394

children.definition: A carveout permitting restricted subsidiaries to guarantee indebtedness of holdings or affiliates, including performance guarantees, financial guarantees, and keepwell agreements. This basket addresses upstream and cross-stream guarantee obligations that do not fall within the standard intra-group guarantee basket because they involve guarantees of parent-level or affiliate-level debt rather than sibling-entity obligations.
children.name: Guarantee
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 88 (incurrence of guarantee or contingent obligations)

children.definition: Alternative formulation for scheduled pre-existing debt. May overlap with the existing debt basket depending on drafting. Typically enumerated in a schedule and capped at the outstanding amount as of closing. Distinguished from the existing debt basket by potentially covering a broader category of legacy obligations.
children.name: Existing Indebtedness
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79

children.definition: Miscellaneous permitted indebtedness baskets covering operational and de minimis obligations that do not fit within the main capacity baskets: customer deposits, insurance premium financing, workers' compensation bonds, performance bonds, equipment financing, de minimis debt, existing debt, guarantees of permitted debt, and subordinated debt. These baskets address ordinary-course operational needs and are generally non-negotiated.

concept_specific_notes: [neg_cov_debt.guarantee] Universal basket (9/9). Added 'guaranties' (plural) — Sleep Number uses this exclusively. Contingent Obligation (7/9, 58 hits) is a defined term capturing guarantees and other contingent liabilities.

[neg_cov_debt.existing_indebtedness] Universal basket (9/9). Grandfather clause for debt existing at closing. Two patterns: (1) 'Indebtedness existing on the Closing Date and listed on Schedule X' (most deals), (2) Named defined term 'Existing Indebtedness' (some deals). Schedule reference is often the best anchor.

[neg_cov_debt.insurance_bonds] Insurance premium financing (8/9) and performance/surety bonds (8/9) are near-universal baskets. Often combined in a single basket clause. 'workers' compensation' and 'appeal bond' catch additional obligations that some deals include in the same basket.

[neg_cov_debt.subordinated] Two patterns: (1) Named basket with 'Subordinated Indebtedness'/'Subordinated Debt' as a defined term (4/9), (2) Subordination as a condition/requirement — 'subordinated to the Obligations' or 'subordinated in right of payment' (5/9 — Caesars, National Vision, Quidel use this). Removed 'Subordination Agreement' (0/9 in debt sections). Absent in Sleep Number (IG-style).
search_strategy.fallback_escalation: Search for 'shall not incur' or 'Permitted Indebtedness' or 'incurrence of Indebtedness'. If none found, search for 'other Indebtedness' or 'aggregate principal amount' near negative covenant headings.
xref_follow: Section 1.01 for Indebtedness/Debt definition
Cross-references to ratio test / Leverage Ratio definition
Cross-references to Permitted Acquisition / Limited Condition Acquisition
Section 2.14/2.20 for Incremental Facility mechanics (incremental_facility basket lives there, not in neg cov section)

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=medium vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: Other Debt Baskets (Decomposed)

red_flags.pattern: No aggregate cap on all 'other' baskets
red_flags.rationale: Sum of parts exceeds intended capacity

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 (indebtedness covenant)

children.definition: Ability to redesignate restricted payment basket capacity to debt incurrence capacity. PC Term Comparison: 'Typically limited to reallocating from RPs to RDPs/Investments and RDPs to Investments but not the other way.' Redesignation from RPs to debt capacity is 'other than in Aggressive UMM/BSLR transactions, reject reallocations to build debt capacity.' KCT Cat 2 Item 1: 'Identify Restricted Payment amount that can be reclassified/reallocated to pari passu debt.'
children.name: From Restricted Payment Baskets
children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison lines 367-370; KCT Cat 2 Item 1

children.definition: Ability to redesignate investment basket capacity to debt incurrence capacity. KCT Cat 2 Item 1: 'Identify amount of Investment baskets that can be reclassified/reallocated to pari passu debt.' PC Term Comparison: reallocation to build debt capacity rejected in non-aggressive transactions. Distinguished from RP redesignation by sourcing from a different covenant's unused capacity.
children.name: From Investment Baskets
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 2 Item 1; PC Term Comparison line 369

children.definition: Ability to redesignate restricted debt payment basket capacity to debt incurrence capacity. PC Term Comparison: direction of reallocation matters — 'Typically limited to reallocating from RPs to RDPs/Investments and RDPs to Investments but not the other way.' RDP-to-debt redesignation is aggressive and generally rejected. Distinguished from RP and investment redesignation by sourcing from junior debt prepayment capacity.
children.name: From Restricted Debt Payment Baskets
children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison lines 367-369

children.definition: Whether redesignation can flow in both directions (e.g., from RP to debt AND from debt to RP). PC Term Comparison: standard direction is RP→RDP→Investment (down the hierarchy only). Bidirectional redesignation allows unused debt capacity to be used for RPs/investments, which is more borrower-favorable. Distinguished from unidirectional redesignation by permitting flow in both directions.
children.name: Bidirectional Redesignation
children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison lines 367-370

children.definition: Ability to redesignate unused capacity from non-debt covenants to debt incurrence capacity. PC Term Comparison: 'Other than in Aggressive UMM/BSLR transactions, reject reallocations to build debt capacity. Otherwise limit to within same covenant.' Learning Material line 1417: 'unused portion of the general debt basket may be reallocated to incremental capacity.' KCT Cat 2 Item 1: 'Identify amount of Investment baskets that can be reclassified/reallocated to pari passu debt.' Distinguished from stacking (which combines baskets within the same incurrence) by transferring capacity across covenant categories.

market_benchmarks.bsl: common; broader redesignation rights across all covenants
market_benchmarks.cmm: uncommon; typically to general basket only
market_benchmarks.lmm: rare; most LMM deals reject cross-covenant redesignation
market_benchmarks.umm: limited redesignation; typically within same covenant family

children.name: Cross-Covenant Redesignation / Reclassification
children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison lines 367-370; Learning Material line 1417; KCT Cat 2 Item 1

children.name: Verification Mechanics
children.definition: How the borrower demonstrates that basket capacity has not been previously utilized — typically through a responsible officer certificate at the time of incurrence identifying the specific basket(s) being utilized and confirming that the amounts have not been previously applied. The verification mechanism is important because without tracking, the borrower could claim the same capacity under multiple baskets simultaneously. KCT Cat 2 Item 1: 'identify baskets (and their respective sizes) that may be stacked, or may be reclassified.'
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 2 Item 1 (basket stacking identification)

children.name: Cross-Basket Tracking Scope
children.definition: Which baskets are subject to the not-previously-used restriction — debt, liens, investments, and restricted payment baskets may all have independent tracking requirements. The cross-basket scope determines whether the anti-stacking rule prevents double-counting only within a single covenant (indebtedness) or across multiple covenants (indebtedness + investments + RPs). PC Term Comparison line 84: 'Include not otherwise applied language throughout agreement to avoid double counting.'
children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 84 (not otherwise applied throughout agreement); KCT Cat 2 Item 1 (stacking)

children.name: Stacking Exceptions
children.definition: Permitted exceptions to the anti-stacking rule, including ratio-based capacity (which by design stacks with fixed baskets because freebie amounts are excluded from ratio calculations), general basket reclassification rights, and specific basket-crossing permissions. DLS Preferred Row 9 (alternative): 'any amounts incurred under the Free and Clear Incremental Amount that is concurrently incurred with amounts under clause (b), shall be excluded from the calculation of the applicable ratio.' This exclusion is the core stacking mechanic.
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 9 (alternative: freebie excluded from ratio calculation); KCT Cat 2 Item 1 (stacking identification)

children.definition: Anti-stacking rule requiring that capacity used for one basket cannot simultaneously be counted toward another. KCT Cat 2 Item 1: 'identify baskets (and their respective sizes) that may be stacked, or may be reclassified to allow the incurrence of additional pari or structurally senior debt.' PC Term Comparison: 'Stacking/Phony Ratio: Clients will consider excluding concurrent revolver draws but will reject excluding revolver outstandings altogether. Ideally limited to ratios for debt incurrence baskets and not for RPs, RDPs or RIs.' The 'not previously used' rule prevents double-counting of the same capacity across baskets.
children.name: Not Previously Used Rule
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 2 Item 1; PC Term Comparison lines 371-373

definition: Negative covenant (typically Section 6.01) prohibiting the borrower and restricted subsidiaries from creating, incurring, assuming, or permitting to exist any indebtedness, except through enumerated basket exceptions. The bank's preferred opening position permits only credit facility debt, a fixed-dollar general basket, and permitted acquisition debt (DLS Preferred Row 79). Aggressive structures add ratio debt, incremental equivalent debt, contribution debt, and numerous other baskets, with the interaction between stacking and reclassification determining total post-closing debt capacity (KCT Cat 2 Item 1).

market_benchmarks.pctc_cmm_lmm: may require subordination terms and other acceptable terms (not cash pay, no covs, later maturity; at Holdco)
market_benchmarks.pctc_umm_bsl: deals (which tend to match BSLs) earnouts should always be debt for the negative covenant (with a corresponding basket; measured at maximum possible obligation per the relevant agreement) and debt for the leverage ratios if due and payable or alternatively past due by more than 5/30 days; transactions will likely match theBSL market here

name: Indebtedness

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position:
Allow side by side revolvers (if permitted must have ROFR and/or pro rata borrowing and prepayments; MFN protection)
Include builder for permanent commitment reductions under the Revolving Facility
(a) the sum (the “Free and Clear Incremental Amount”) of [...]
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market landing between lender-preferred and borrower-aggressive positions; specific terms deal-dependent.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Permitted debt limited to Credit Facility + fixed-dollar general basket; no standalone ratio basket outside the facility

definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 79 (bank preferred: 3 baskets only); KCT Cat 2 Items 1-4 (stacking/reclassification risks)
